</td><td>\u22126.42\u00a0</td><td>0.69\u00a0</td><td>23.16\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11\u00a0</td><td>21.61\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>20.92\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>20.82\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09\u00a0</td><td>20.45\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>D\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.13\u00a0</td><td>2.96\u00a0</td><td>20.86\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>20.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>20.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>20.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>20.51\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G1\u00a0</td><td>\u22123.31\u00a0</td><td>1.58\u00a0</td><td>22.61\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.16\u00a0</td><td>20.52\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>19.51\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>19.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>19.12\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>G3\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.10\u00a0</td><td>1.63\u00a0</td><td>22.09\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.16\u00a0</td><td>21.80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.17\u00a0</td><td>21.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.21\u00a0</td><td>&gt;21.20\u00a0</td><td>&gt;20.85\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98082937\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082938 id=\"98082938\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Lens stellar mass</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>grizY</em> SED inferred for the main deflector galaxy G1 can be used to estimate its stellar mass. We used the public<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> version of FAST (Kriek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Motivated by Treu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), we adopt a Salpeter stellar IMF, which is expected for massive early-type galaxies. A direct measurement of the lens velocity dispersion would enable an IMF-independent determination of the stellar mass (Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). The best-fitting model is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. With the uncertainties from the SED modelling, we obtain <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10}(M_{\\star }/\\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}) = 11.49^{+0.46}_{-0.32}$|\u2060</span>. We will compare this to the results of lens models in the next section. Once again, while we used the more uncertain <em>grizY</em> magnitudes (to remain on the cautionary side), the inferred stellar mass does not depend appreciably on the PSF chosen to model the cutout.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98082940 id=\"98082940\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 LENS MODELS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The three images A, B, D have compatible SEDs, as is also confirmed by their long-slit spectra by Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We can then use their positions relative to G1 to model this system as a gravitational lens, obtaining estimates of the total mass (within the Einstein radius) and predicted time-delays between different images. Since G2/C is substantially redder than the other components, we do not include it in the lens model, but rather compare its properties with those predicted by the lens model fit to the other components. The technicalities of the lens model are described in Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Conservatively, we adopt 0.2\u2009arcsec positional uncertainties on A, B, D and 0.3\u2009arcsec on G1, G2/C, about twice as large as those from the cutout modelling of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> (relying solely on the DES cutouts). This allows us to explore a wide family of lens models and draw some general conclusions, in particular on the flux ratios allowed by different models. In one case, we also allow the positional uncertainties to be those given directly by the cutout modelling (last line of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). The inferred lens model parameters for all models are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We stress that we are not using the smaller uncertainties from the WFI deconvolution, in order to highlight the robustness of some conclusions that held already with DES-quality data. However, when ellipticity is included in the lens model (defined as \u2018SIE\u2019 below), its p.a. agrees well with that from the WFI images shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98082943\" scrollto-destination=\"98082943\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inferred lens model parameters in the case of a Singular Isothermal Ellipsoid (SIE, first row), a Singular Isothermal Sphere plus external shear (SIS+XS, second row), or the same plus a small perturber G2 where G2/C is observed in the DES cutouts, adopting 0.2\u2009arcsec for the positional uncertainties of <em>A, B, D</em> and 0.3\u2009arcsec for those of G1 and G2. For reference, the notation is fully explained in the main text. The number of degrees of freedom of each model corresponds simply to the number of parameters that are not kept fixed in this table. The lens p.a. of G1 (which may be different from that of its starlight) is quoted in \u2018mathematical notation\u2019 N of W, corresponding to \u224830\u2009deg E of N. The perturber Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E, <em>p</em></sub> is not an additional parameter, being inferred directly from <em>b<sub>p</sub></em> and <em>s<sub>p</sub></em>. Models with a sub-critical G2 (<em>s<sub>p</sub></em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0<em>b<sub>p</sub></em>/2) are not excluded. <sup>(<em>a</em>)</sup>This line shows the average parameters and standard deviations obtained when all uncertainties on positions are set to 0.1\u2009arcsec. <sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup> The two bottom lines list the lens parameters form a model with G1 plus one (upper) or two (lower) perturbers with free positions, and flux ratios as additional constraints (Section 3.3.2). Letters in square brackets indicate the image next to which the perturbers lie.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E, l</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<sub>l</sub> (N of W)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<sub>s</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c6<sub>s</sub> (N of W)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>b<sub>p</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>s<sub>p</sub></em>/<em>b<sub>p</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E, <em>p</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n href=\"/view-large/98082943\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inferred lens model parameters in the case of a Singular Isothermal Ellipsoid (SIE, first row), a Singular Isothermal Sphere plus external shear (SIS+XS, second row), or the same plus a small perturber G2 where G2/C is observed in the DES cutouts, adopting 0.2\u2009arcsec for the positional uncertainties of <em>A, B, D</em> and 0.3\u2009arcsec for those of G1 and G2. For reference, the notation is fully explained in the main text. The number of degrees of freedom of each model corresponds simply to the number of parameters that are not kept fixed in this table. The lens p.a. of G1 (which may be different from that of its starlight) is quoted in \u2018mathematical notation\u2019 N of W, corresponding to \u224830\u2009deg E of N. The perturber Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E, <em>p</em></sub> is not an additional parameter, being inferred directly from <em>b<sub>p</sub></em> and <em>s<sub>p</sub></em>. Models with a sub-critical G2 (<em>s<sub>p</sub></em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0<em>b<sub>p</sub></em>/2) are not excluded. <sup>(<em>a</em>)</sup>This line shows the average parameters and standard deviations obtained when all uncertainties on positions are set to 0.1\u2009arcsec. <sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup> The two bottom lines list the lens parameters form a model with G1 plus one (upper) or two (lower) perturbers with free positions, and flux ratios as additional constraints (Section 3.3.2). Letters in square brackets indicate the image next to which the perturbers lie.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E, l</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" [C]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+XS+2p<sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup>\u00a0</td><td>(1.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.93\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>\u221259.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.3\u00a0</td><td>0.004\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.032\u00a0</td><td>19.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.2\u00a0</td><td>(0.40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>(0.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07)\u2009arcsec [C]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>(0.44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.05\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>(0.42\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06)\u2009arcsec [D]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98082943\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The images A, B, D are mapped to the source plane according to the lens equation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s} = \\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im}-\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }-\\boldsymbol{\\Gamma }\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\theta } = (\\delta x, \\delta y)$|</span> is the angular displacement relative to the best-fitting G1 centre from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, the <em>external shear</em> matrix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\Gamma }$|</span> is defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\boldsymbol{\\Gamma } = \\gamma _{s}\\, \\left(\\begin{array}{cc}\\cos (2\\varphi _{s}) &amp; \\sin (2\\varphi _{s}) \\\\\r\n\\sin (2\\varphi _{s}) &amp; -\\cos (2\\varphi _{s}) \\end{array} \\right)\\\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }$|</span> depends on how we describe the deflections by lensing galaxies. When describing lens galaxies, we use parametric models for their convergence profiles \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3<sub><em>cr</em></sub>, where \u03a3<sub><em>cr</em></sub> = c<sup>2</sup><em>D<sub>s</sub></em>/(4\u03c0G<em>D<sub>l</sub>D<sub>ls</sub></em>) accounts for the dimensional dependence on angular-diameter distances. In particular, we use a Pseudo-Isothermal Ellipsoidal Mass Profile (PIEMD; Kassiola &amp; Kovner\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>). This model provides a good representation of the gravitational potential of lens galaxies (e.g. Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60a\" data-open=\"bib60a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the deflection angles <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }$|</span> in coordinates (<em>X, Y</em>) aligned with the principal axes of the iso-density ellipsoids <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\alpha _{X} = -\\frac{b}{\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} \\arctan \\left(\\frac{X\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}{s+\\sqrt{q^{2}(s^{2}+X^{2})+Y^{2}}}\\right)\\!,\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\alpha _{Y} = -\\frac{b}{\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} {\\rm arctanh} \\left(\\frac{Y\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}{q^{2}s+\\sqrt{q^{2}(s^{2}+X^{2})+Y^{2}}}\\right)\\!,\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>are fully analytic, together with the convergence and the Fermat potential. The expression in coordinates (<em>x, y</em>) in West-North orientation requires just rotations in the coordinates and deflections, for which we choose the lens long-axis p.a. \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> as positive N of W. The spherical (<em>q</em> \u2192 1) and core-less (<em>s</em>/<em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a00) limit reduces to the Singular Isothermal Sphere (SIS), for which <em>b</em> is also the Einstein radius <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> enclosing a mean convergence of 1. In the Singular Isothermal Ellipsoid (SIE) case (<em>q</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01, <em>s</em>/<em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a00), with the above notation we have <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R_{\\rm E} = b/\\sqrt{q}$|</span> as the ellipsoidal coordinate of the contour enclosing \u3008\u03ba\u3009\u00a0=\u00a01. In the case where <em>q</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 but <em>s</em>/<em>b</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00, the Einstein radius is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R_{\\rm E} = b\\sqrt{1-2s/R_{\\rm E}}$|\u2060</span>, which means that the PIEMD can be sub-critical (\u03ba\u00a0&lt;\u00a01 everywhere) when <em>s</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0<em>b</em>/2. The Einstein radius can be used to estimate the lens velocity dispersion via<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\sigma _{\\rm sis} = {\\rm c}\\sqrt{\\frac{R_{\\rm E}D_{s}}{4\\pi D_{l}D_{ls}}} \\ = 203\\, (\\theta _{\\rm E}/1\\text{ arcsec})^{1/2}\\, \\rm {km\\, s^{-1}}\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>while the projected mass within <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nM_{p}(R_{\\text{E}}) = \\pi \\Sigma _{\\rm cr}R_{\\text{E}}^{2} \\ = 2.0*10^{11}(\\theta _{\\rm E}/1\\text{ arcsec})^{2}\\, \\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}\\, ,\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>regardless of the lens model. Here and in what follows, \u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>R</em><sub>E</sub>/<em>D<sub>l</sub></em> is the Einstein radius in angular units, the same as for the lens strength parameter <em>b</em>.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082945 id=\"98082945\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Models with one deflector</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For the first models, we describe the lensing mass distribution as given solely by G1. The first model (SIE) comprises simply a SIE representing G1. The second model (SIS+XS) adopts an SIS for G1, with the addition of external shear with non-null \u03b3<sub><em>s</em></sub>. The resulting parameters are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Both the SIE and SIS+XS models reproduce the positions of images A,B,D and predict a saddle-point image \u2018C\u2019 near the position G2/C found in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), whose relative position can vary from model to model, still within one or two DES pixels. The inferred Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E, <em>l</em></sub> of G1 is slightly less than half the A-to-B image separation (\u22482.2\u2009arcsec), due to quadrupole contributions to the deflection either by ellipticity or by shear.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> The lens velocity dispersion and mass within <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> can be estimated as (286\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06) km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and (7.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6)10<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> [resp. (280\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06) km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and (7.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6)10<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>] for the SIE (resp. SIS+XS) model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Models with just one central deflector predict that image \u2018C\u2019 should be about as bright as image \u2018B\u2019, even with relatively large adopted uncertainties on the image positions (0.2\u2033 instead of 0.09\u2009arcsec). This is summarized in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, and in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98082949\" scrollto-destination=\"98082949\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=TxEEQhOJlcJH3x6rOiCKIgyfxOTYJX55IrFJ3awQEK23yfkG4zXKENJo3dcez0yTRjgMVlSfr53FjEte-ZqkSE4wQzsL~DJm9voJvTreC5-XGgSZJQGERhbbdsYAeYPlY-a6RSpXrlhbC9uM0EWmKh3p4RvwRzV3~zXVP4o3ud3p8msg83eBbNu4-I7a4ldhiFbhqJdK~2V-NJFDmhTXEf4kBCjgF4c54wdop3sJH~MVyguVIHt3ItBOxpgcrPBwrZKUuYlmCW3MRIr0y70E0BfydriqvueXX8p8-KXhQFioLKPQwM--bXyyevHJHEpGuqfKNRDHeu83PAZFaw5ppw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Output magnifications from a model with one SIE in the lens plane; the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior (no parameters held fixed). While the magnifications of B and D relative to A are in qualitative agreement with the SED fit results, the predicted image C should be almost as bright as image B and appreciably brighter than image A. This is not observed even after differential reddening is added to fit the colours (Section 2), and so it cannot be solely the result of dust extinction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082949/stx2242fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082949\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=h1fmOgqkWgxqQFm~jIBisO4avvEJ0lwaSBQhiYPlTDJxjMS2ioYXRcJLkcwkLPd6sTol7cOwLGFXZpZTG1UJWW4cqedd5WUKAZvLeq5vTTMbJT5DbPizur3A-0yoVHURd5GuUQaCu4f4BiVbd0GFQXj6y2F3ByT-RiE8tdOmLs3N1nU2g6DEI27A6IpaGvV4N8r4YI~n3-swCgl1xr1DSAakj4HrXy0uMe2DHue4yD0GXvhlHlSE-bmPrkesmE7KwfrETGIdNyi-gyaLNTEVXpzi5FS5iZ-KulBR0dk~wC5R1Sz2BR4ERPjZdFvVBogp3dQ3~kHUd~xqzng-X3aKQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082949&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Output magnifications from a model with one SIE in the lens plane; the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior (no parameters held fixed). While the magnifications of B and D relative to A are in qualitative agreement with the SED fit results, the predicted image C should be almost as bright as image B and appreciably brighter than image A. This is not observed even after differential reddening is added to fit the colours (Section 2), and so it cannot be solely the result of dust extinction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=TxEEQhOJlcJH3x6rOiCKIgyfxOTYJX55IrFJ3awQEK23yfkG4zXKENJo3dcez0yTRjgMVlSfr53FjEte-ZqkSE4wQzsL~DJm9voJvTreC5-XGgSZJQGERhbbdsYAeYPlY-a6RSpXrlhbC9uM0EWmKh3p4RvwRzV3~zXVP4o3ud3p8msg83eBbNu4-I7a4ldhiFbhqJdK~2V-NJFDmhTXEf4kBCjgF4c54wdop3sJH~MVyguVIHt3ItBOxpgcrPBwrZKUuYlmCW3MRIr0y70E0BfydriqvueXX8p8-KXhQFioLKPQwM--bXyyevHJHEpGuqfKNRDHeu83PAZFaw5ppw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Output magnifications from a model with one SIE in the lens plane; the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior (no parameters held fixed). While the magnifications of B and D relative to A are in qualitative agreement with the SED fit results, the predicted image C should be almost as bright as image B and appreciably brighter than image A. This is not observed even after differential reddening is added to fit the colours (Section 2), and so it cannot be solely the result of dust extinction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082949/stx2242fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082949\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=h1fmOgqkWgxqQFm~jIBisO4avvEJ0lwaSBQhiYPlTDJxjMS2ioYXRcJLkcwkLPd6sTol7cOwLGFXZpZTG1UJWW4cqedd5WUKAZvLeq5vTTMbJT5DbPizur3A-0yoVHURd5GuUQaCu4f4BiVbd0GFQXj6y2F3ByT-RiE8tdOmLs3N1nU2g6DEI27A6IpaGvV4N8r4YI~n3-swCgl1xr1DSAakj4HrXy0uMe2DHue4yD0GXvhlHlSE-bmPrkesmE7KwfrETGIdNyi-gyaLNTEVXpzi5FS5iZ-KulBR0dk~wC5R1Sz2BR4ERPjZdFvVBogp3dQ3~kHUd~xqzng-X3aKQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082949&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Output magnifications from a model with one SIE in the lens plane; the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior (no parameters held fixed). While the magnifications of B and D relative to A are in qualitative agreement with the SED fit results, the predicted image C should be almost as bright as image B and appreciably brighter than image A. This is not observed even after differential reddening is added to fit the colours (Section 2), and so it cannot be solely the result of dust extinction.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"98082950\" scrollto-destination=\"98082950\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inferred <em>logarithmic</em> magnifications for the three models fit to positions of A,B,D and G1, with one SIE (top) or SIS+XS (middle) in the lens plane, or with the addition of a perturber at G2/C (bottom). The first line of each block is log<sub>10</sub>(\u03bc) from the best-fitting model, while the second line shows the mean and standard deviation from the MCMC posterior. The last column lists the predicted displacement of image <em>C</em>, in terms of West-ward and North-ward displacements from the best-fitting position of <em>G</em>1 from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> (identified with \u03b4<em>x</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03b4<em>y</em>\u00a0=\u00a00). The positional uncertainties are systematics-dominated, as the predicted position (especially <em>y</em><sub>C</sub>) can change appreciably across models.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>log<sub>10</sub>\u03bc(<em>A</em>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>log<sub>10</sub>\u03bc(<em>B</em>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>log<sub>10</sub>\u03bc(<em>D</em>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>log<sub>10</sub>\u03bc(<em>C</em>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>x</em><sub>C</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>x</em><sub>G1</sub> (\u2033)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>y</em><sub>C</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>y</em><sub>G1</sub> (\u2033)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n       </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inferred <em>logarithmic</em> magnifications for the three models fit to positions of A,B,D and G1, with one SIE (top) or SIS+XS (middle) in the lens plane, or with the addition of a perturber at G2/C (bottom). The first line of each block is log<sub>10</sub>(\u03bc) from the best-fitting model, while the second line shows the mean and standard deviation from the MCMC posterior. The last column lists the predicted displacement of image <em>C</em>, in terms of West-ward and North-ward displacements from the best-fitting position of <em>G</em>1 from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> (identified with \u03b4<em>x</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03b4<em>y</em>\u00a0=\u00a00). The positional uncertainties are systematics-dominated, as the predicted position (especially <em>y</em><sub>C</sub>) can change appreciably across models.</p></div> </div><div       </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"98082951\" scrollto-destination=\"98082951\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Time-delays predicted by different lens models, adopting flat-\u039bCDM cosmology with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. Models using 0.2\u2009arcsec positional errors have large time-delay uncertainties and posteriors that are very skewed from those of the best-fitting solution. The delays from models with free perturbers are in coarse agreement with those subsequently measured by Courbin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), but sharper and deeper imaging data are needed for proper modelling and comparison.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Model<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394<em>t</em><sub>BD</sub> (d)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394<em>t</em><sub>BC</sub> (d)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SIE\u00a0</td><td>125\u00a0</td><td>20\u00a0</td><td>8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+XS\u00a0</td><td>100\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0</td><td>2.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+XS+G2\u00a0</td><td>87\u00a0</td><td>29\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+XS+1p\u00a0</td><td>135.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a012.5\u00a0</td><td>21.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.5\u00a0</td><td>1.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+XS+2p\u00a0</td><td>140.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a012.0\u00a0</td><td>14.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.4\u00a0</td><td>0.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.0\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98082951\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082952 id=\"98082952\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Models with perturbers</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The first saddle-point predicted by models with one deflector would fall near the position of G2, which however is appreciably redder than the other images and significantly fainter than predicted even in the reddest bands. Extinction as measured in other lensed quasars (Dai et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Mediavilla et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) does not differ substantially to that measured in the Milky Way and Magellanic Clouds (e.g. Cardelli et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>). However, while the simple addition of a standard reddening law<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> to the SED of image B can reproduce the colours of image G2/C, it still requires a \u2018grey\u2019 dimming of \u22480.8\u2009mag in each band to match its overall magnitudes as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=98082954 id=\"98082954\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-1>3.2.1 Fixed perturber at G2/C</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since G2/C lies close to image B, the differential reddening should be produced by a local overdensity, such as a small galaxy, whose lensing effect can also alter the magnification of image C. In general, saddle-points of the Fermat potential are <em>suppressed</em>, i.e. dimmed, by the presence of nearby perturbers, whereas minima fluctuate less (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Keeton\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For this reason, we add a galaxy at the location of G2/C, which we describe as a PIEMD with <em>q</em>\u00a0=\u00a01. The addition of a perturber at a fixed position increases the number of parameters by two (core size and Einstein radius), making the model underconstrained. However, we can still rely on the priors on positions given by Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, and examine the range of parameter configurations that are compatible with the observed image configuration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For simplicity, and due to the lack of an independent redshift measurement, we place the perturber in the same plane of the main lens G1. In general, models of lenses with four images have degeneracies among the monopole and quadrupole parameters (Kochanek, Schneider &amp; Wambsganss\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). As verified above, the SIS+XS and SIE models do not differ appreciably in the output image positions and magnifications (Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The inferred lens parameters of the new model (with a main lens G1 and a perturber G2), given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, suggest a fairly small (\u22480.2\u2009arcsec) Einstein radius and do not rule out a sub-critical perturber. Even when <em>s<sub>p</sub></em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>b<sub>p</sub></em>/2, the formation of multiple images and their magnifications depend on the distance between the perturber and image C; even though this does not occur in this configuration, the constraint that multiple images are not produced by the perturber (or not observed) could be used if sharper and deeper data are available. Similarly to the findings of Nierenberg et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) on a different lens, limits on how massive the perturber can be are given simply by the requirement that the other images (A,B,D) are not shifted by the perturber beyond their measured uncertainties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With the addition of G2 in the lens model, the predicted image \u2018C\u2019 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>) is suppressed by the presence of the small perturber, making it slightly fainter than image A (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). With a small perturber at \u22480.2\u2009arcsec from image C West-ward and South-ward, its SED can be easily reddened even though it lies very close to B. The small separation between C and G2 makes them hardly distinguishable even in the Gemini acquisition image of Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), whose PSF has a quoted FWHM\u22480.5\u2009arcsec. Within this model, the lens velocity dispersion of G1 is (267\u00a0\u00b1\u00a012) km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and its projected mass within <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> is (6.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0)10<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Even though G2 is not excluded to be sub-critical, we can still estimate its velocity dispersion and enclosed projected mass as (95\u00a0\u00b1\u00a017) km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and \u2272 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"98082960\" scrollto-destination=\"98082960\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=0goyaCYPVYmxt1LfYCDhSS4XQ72IxPbMJ-aQyzDwqZmF9oNGep9LGPlvHptRpzKM8hX4KoAkgwajx3vKsKUTrjQPQ20CwIQu8xOR2tOt7bA-Vxp27~kL6rGZgwZ7COeYwm9-va9UjftvK5d61HDmaYc7CoY3AR5PSEqCN3Mf7IYLXoRFuM3uQDBy4EGhGD~U1Zq1T0xNrhJc2EVk6IPJYHShR-NNTCbpQIN50B9StCG174OR0Sf1KPtPrl9BqKzZ-593P3bf8LCxiLEE-wJpM4p90rUuE50R2ON4nYdKKhyxpSYOcaDkGDuB1~Tx4vVY2fOC4ZZpW5VtIDN0Bo~vYg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Time-delay contours for the case with one SIS plus external shear (left panel) or with the addition of a perturber at G2 (right). Models generally predict the fourth image position within one pixel-length in each direction from G2. This has a magnification comparable to that of image B if no perturber is present nearby. Being a saddle-point image, its magnification is easily suppressed by the presence of a small perturber at G2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082960/stx2242fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082960\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=zso48YJXQtiLzDnbFOCfQuIhGVfWNpaWXohGGWfC52nxk0loQnZ22h0uJv8W~Mumz52zY07GTc7YE5yZqUmrZTcQVL06LfP8SwF2Lmyg3VTqo0AxLrvq5CAvavU-de79dPo6BAtpbYj9xhixt0VXaXpdrINJXTRq7Df7kTTtq-8th~eyoA6TynyLpchL08U7RJ7GEFK-dYV486JD55GhXlPegljHyNeOKNbwzdplr6M2UGQxE-M3I9jo9efVrBcF5wqE8iQ99ZNDVOfdVgQVM7I3--H93g9tSqigE4Fo8o1j8K5WhWj~Q-pbyLQ4iVlf9OOe2S4TSMVxKfKUPBtGdQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082960&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Time-delay contours for the case with one SIS plus external shear (<em>left</em> panel) or with the addition of a perturber at <em>G</em>2 (<em>right</em>). Models generally predict the fourth image position within one pixel-length in each direction from <em>G</em>2. This has a magnification comparable to that of image B if no perturber is present nearby. Being a saddle-point image, its magnification is easily suppressed by the presence of a small perturber at <em>G</em>2.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=0goyaCYPVYmxt1LfYCDhSS4XQ72IxPbMJ-aQyzDwqZmF9oNGep9LGPlvHptRpzKM8hX4KoAkgwajx3vKsKUTrjQPQ20CwIQu8xOR2tOt7bA-Vxp27~kL6rGZgwZ7COeYwm9-va9UjftvK5d61HDmaYc7CoY3AR5PSEqCN3Mf7IYLXoRFuM3uQDBy4EGhGD~U1Zq1T0xNrhJc2EVk6IPJYHShR-NNTCbpQIN50B9StCG174OR0Sf1KPtPrl9BqKzZ-593P3bf8LCxiLEE-wJpM4p90rUuE50R2ON4nYdKKhyxpSYOcaDkGDuB1~Tx4vVY2fOC4ZZpW5VtIDN0Bo~vYg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Time-delay contours for the case with one SIS plus external shear (left panel) or with the addition of a perturber at G2 (right).
