Adding a perturber (G2) at the observed location of G2/C dims image C considerably.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082961/stx2242fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082961\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=VLz485TBpEt5DY3vpIu6tS6nIIj~LBxoedXzzZvebtwGUFLQOXpc3v26jq6VH-TapKUwbPUnwC4CvR9WIADJIwVd0G5RDXqcj6dVAtMHxQktHhWpNa0Py0k5lFBBrZu87BQmcJ8nzEDLW2v7ElsjIr37iLznTW-o~8Cz~7aJhUBoLX1ZqvnvtVFcvgEdANIjlJWxqqIzEQtIuZo3yVcQJyvLMkqVWD0JFnFeCXnWbVe2PUyJvJlcRXLXc~23K7MVjzrCT6KlopamuuB5auOOXC-b58j~cPWB4evdu7~M4hLv8g1fwfroUi2PVGO0lFXK2Tp5mWsL5aAuwwSaLj8MGg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082961&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Output magnifications from a model SIE (top), SIS+XS (middle), and SIS+XS+G2 (bottom, see the text), in logarithmic units. The SIE and SIS+XS models produce similar results, particularly for the predicted ordering of magnifications. Adding a perturber (G2) at the observed location of G2/C dims image C considerably.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"98082962\" scrollto-destination=\"98082962\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=AND5eJkEr1WSPkVhYTWHr8QLFTdWBdozieIxjNWHDbFWa3Ch0jh5ERvOn1862I9rPjHUh2pQOtI1N-fUhrYDpQp2jeAWUvKvAQ3EYrcdVCgQP-TcjVrKfJaMtVL93oeLQC9rL7e~r0Hdbt6btb2k96fNEgft9ZUKTv82yU5O3DFfMrXbdZ2C0oJune2pfumU9XNAWqxyjJw8BoLOmr5ar4RUSXSSVgIVhZZXif3M1DG4z1kB-kjzs5y20~BenSK70kPtBldmaSqfL5bXG1~VB98fpaj9cFevv-0RA--oBrgW7TfCj4nZ-UcDKi0cM2IweBWeCafsIk9gBaDoAa5BqQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Output magnifications from a model with SIS+XS plus a small perturber (G2) at the observed location of G2/C; again, the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior. Within this class of models, both images C and D are slightly fainter than image A and significantly fainter than image B, even before dust extinction is accounted for. This saddle-point suppression is excessive on image C, due to the proximity of G2. For this reason, we explore models where one or two perturbers have free position parameters, and flux ratios (corrected for dust and light curve delays) are used as constraints (see the text, Fig.\u00a09).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082962/stx2242fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082962\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=p57ib9BZuNp5eOX91jHLsTzzlJhSBmRb2QHRc~g4F3f9yigcsnet~GbWE07oK0mCDemOQT2OSnRHNIIXzpviySn-b7pX0qWCqjb1-72EkQLX2pbvTwBAIi3cI1hmrWmKbReBWslF8CmsusyBNrZ0jxiKhPeJNktW9HmeiN1ZXC-arHeGfTJvfJA9CC8hhh3MNPOPa9EoyG5y-11gSa8nzF0Juv8YsOrx9F4Ik2xQZBxuy8OQLeI~vycJNnrnJI2jwtxsBke9RZEAJ-nFqy8FMJE993fYhUFB77Ne24lPGhSH6bcRN1KTF9Q3henwH9lV5z1fItBVf1ZWEvYCiG1YHw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082962&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Output magnifications from a model with SIS+XS plus a small perturber (G2) at the observed location of G2/C; again, the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior. Within this class of models, both images C and D are slightly fainter than image A and significantly fainter than image B, even before dust extinction is accounted for. This saddle-point suppression is excessive on image C, due to the proximity of G2. For this reason, we explore models where one or two perturbers have free position parameters, and flux ratios (corrected for dust and light curve delays) are used as constraints (see the text, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=AND5eJkEr1WSPkVhYTWHr8QLFTdWBdozieIxjNWHDbFWa3Ch0jh5ERvOn1862I9rPjHUh2pQOtI1N-fUhrYDpQp2jeAWUvKvAQ3EYrcdVCgQP-TcjVrKfJaMtVL93oeLQC9rL7e~r0Hdbt6btb2k96fNEgft9ZUKTv82yU5O3DFfMrXbdZ2C0oJune2pfumU9XNAWqxyjJw8BoLOmr5ar4RUSXSSVgIVhZZXif3M1DG4z1kB-kjzs5y20~BenSK70kPtBldmaSqfL5bXG1~VB98fpaj9cFevv-0RA--oBrgW7TfCj4nZ-UcDKi0cM2IweBWeCafsIk9gBaDoAa5BqQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Output magnifications from a model with SIS+XS plus a small perturber (G2) at the observed location of G2/C; again, the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior. Within this class of models, both images C and D are slightly fainter than image A and significantly fainter than image B, even before dust extinction is accounted for. This saddle-point suppression is excessive on image C, due to the proximity of G2. For this reason, we explore models where one or two perturbers have free position parameters, and flux ratios (corrected for dust and light curve delays) are used as constraints (see the text, Fig.\u00a09).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082962/stx2242fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082962\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=p57ib9BZuNp5eOX91jHLsTzzlJhSBmRb2QHRc~g4F3f9yigcsnet~GbWE07oK0mCDemOQT2OSnRHNIIXzpviySn-b7pX0qWCqjb1-72EkQLX2pbvTwBAIi3cI1hmrWmKbReBWslF8CmsusyBNrZ0jxiKhPeJNktW9HmeiN1ZXC-arHeGfTJvfJA9CC8hhh3MNPOPa9EoyG5y-11gSa8nzF0Juv8YsOrx9F4Ik2xQZBxuy8OQLeI~vycJNnrnJI2jwtxsBke9RZEAJ-nFqy8FMJE993fYhUFB77Ne24lPGhSH6bcRN1KTF9Q3henwH9lV5z1fItBVf1ZWEvYCiG1YHw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082962&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Output magnifications from a model with SIS+XS plus a small perturber (G2) at the observed location of G2/C; again, the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior. Within this class of models, both images C and D are slightly fainter than image A and significantly fainter than image B, even before dust extinction is accounted for. This saddle-point suppression is excessive on image C, due to the proximity of G2. For this reason, we explore models where one or two perturbers have free position parameters, and flux ratios (corrected for dust and light curve delays) are used as constraints (see the text, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=98082963 id=\"98082963\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-2>3.2.2 Perturbers with free positions</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A perturber (G2) at the location of G2/C, with constraints set only by the relative image positions, is even too effective at saddle-point suppression. In fact, the magnifications predicted by that model (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) are to be meant <em>before</em> dust-extinction, which in this case is substantial, as mentioned in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Then, in order to properly assess the presence of a perturber, one must correct the magnitudes from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> for dust-extinction, microlensing and delays in the light curves, and use those as constraints to the lens models. The long-slit spectra (Lin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) show some microlensing, in that flux ratios among emission lines are different from flux ratios among the continua, but the amount is small ( \u2248 10percent) and, to our aim, negligible in the wavelength range 6000\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u03bb\u00a0&lt;\u00a010\u2009000\u2009\u00c5. Differential reddening can be inferred quite robustly from the differences in colours among different images, as mentioned above. In order to correct for variability, one needs shifted light curves from a monitoring campaign. In what follows, we use shifted magnitudes from the 2.2m-WFI campaign (Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), correct them for differential extinction and neglect microlensing effects. The grey dimming on image C is robust since its delay from image B is small.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we analyse two models with perturbers with free positions, Einstein radii and core radii. In the first case, one perturber near the fold pair (B,C) is added to the primary deflector (G1), and a magnitude difference <em>m</em><sub>C</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.5log<sub>10</sub>(\u03bc<sub>B</sub>/\u03bc<sub>C</sub>)\u00a0=\u00a0(0.85\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1) is added as constraint. In the second case, a second perturber is added near image D and the dust-corrected, delay corrected magnitude differences <em>m</em><sub>D</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub>A</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(0.45\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05), <em>m</em><sub>A</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(1.95\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05) (Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) are additionally used as constraints. The model with two perturbers is explored because a model with just one perturber predicts higher magnifications for image D than are observed. As a model for G1, we adopt an SIE+XS with the following priors: uniform in 1.3\u2009arcsec\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>b<sub>l</sub></em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02.2\u2009arcsec, 0.0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0\u03b3<sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.14, 0.5\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>q</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.99; Gaussian in \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(\u221260.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05.0)\u2009deg, \u03d5<sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(20.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05.0)\u2009deg. Uniform priors are used for the parameters of the perturbers. The inferred parameters are appended in the two bottom lines of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and positions sampled from the posteriors are displayed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. The \u2018butterfly\u2019 pattern in the allowed perturber positions is common to other lenses (e.g. Nierenberg et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"98082966\" scrollto-destination=\"98082966\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=PbAMLADTEkfpNgq67ZsiG0FyTNrFTeyGGMfB4Mmrj-~cBiuvlaz0QWDIn0FVv6lvDsyq8ACg~4HraWSLkiTeFcgH~UAms2GuoBtX4VUNxidjwB7fwors5Dd~H6-IQugiulYRyD3uOTvXFzlF-ypKM8JmMvEZw-yfn0O578R7CwmfAhnofDWCU1XByyrEU71fxh7cKP8hmOaxWaamEFcO8Vzhd1Yv4j-0M2zWiYBIGC8soM9h-ihISJtiISzv3h7G1As0S8r2s9xlS5RPI6tHsXu9sd1QGg0fSjB5t5bFW47bnNzGkdKj4Qw-Cjh4IM2sYL8YtGMRvzu4b9sVrgd~zg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Positions of G1 (red), perturbers (grey) and model-predicted quasar images (blue) as sampled from the posteriors with one (top) or two (bottom) perturbers with free positions. The black star-symbols mark the image positions (relative to G1) from Section\u00a02.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082966/stx2242fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082966\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=y4ehK3Ah37hn7S3VX~duof9-x10kd9ANQ0Bs4DZdo4by0FQx3KVcT4JKnsBfXGQFsOAJ9AMk7rx2sYGHI7Rrv~H4ZRxa28VkPTki0w3hB3Haia~pHwFW1H8sG1p~NEBobr7nQ7dpE6AaZ2hkEvD9zCOZrH~fyL53F4UmYLSCIpvazDwpzgkb4GM2aD9tGGocwzAjNAFGMPUJbyAboljkkiOX0W-pGYixU2m~H7MwVI-i1IuWjOWgfmtvyub5nm9YCcLwmI-A5Yrst2HTqV~kAPHUoC0Ng7~zSGdBophWsu8mKf9YiB23XFKUw6JdGlQ6ZTP2b8wZab3Z76yrSpbMXg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082966&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Positions of G1 (red), perturbers (grey) and model-predicted quasar images (blue) as sampled from the posteriors with one (<em>top</em>) or two (<em>bottom</em>) perturbers with free positions. The black star-symbols mark the image positions (relative to G1) from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=PbAMLADTEkfpNgq67ZsiG0FyTNrFTeyGGMfB4Mmrj-~cBiuvlaz0QWDIn0FVv6lvDsyq8ACg~4HraWSLkiTeFcgH~UAms2GuoBtX4VUNxidjwB7fwors5Dd~H6-IQugiulYRyD3uOTvXFzlF-ypKM8JmMvEZw-yfn0O578R7CwmfAhnofDWCU1XByyrEU71fxh7cKP8hmOaxWaamEFcO8Vzhd1Yv4j-0M2zWiYBIGC8soM9h-ihISJtiISzv3h7G1As0S8r2s9xlS5RPI6tHsXu9sd1QGg0fSjB5t5bFW47bnNzGkdKj4Qw-Cjh4IM2sYL8YtGMRvzu4b9sVrgd~zg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Positions of G1 (red), perturbers (grey) and model-predicted quasar images (blue) as sampled from the posteriors with one (top) or two (bottom) perturbers with free positions. The black star-symbols mark the image positions (relative to G1) from Section\u00a02.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082966/stx2242fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082966\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=y4ehK3Ah37hn7S3VX~duof9-x10kd9ANQ0Bs4DZdo4by0FQx3KVcT4JKnsBfXGQFsOAJ9AMk7rx2sYGHI7Rrv~H4ZRxa28VkPTki0w3hB3Haia~pHwFW1H8sG1p~NEBobr7nQ7dpE6AaZ2hkEvD9zCOZrH~fyL53F4UmYLSCIpvazDwpzgkb4GM2aD9tGGocwzAjNAFGMPUJbyAboljkkiOX0W-pGYixU2m~H7MwVI-i1IuWjOWgfmtvyub5nm9YCcLwmI-A5Yrst2HTqV~kAPHUoC0Ng7~zSGdBophWsu8mKf9YiB23XFKUw6JdGlQ6ZTP2b8wZab3Z76yrSpbMXg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082966&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Positions of G1 (red), perturbers (grey) and model-predicted quasar images (blue) as sampled from the posteriors with one (<em>top</em>) or two (<em>bottom</em>) perturbers with free positions. The black star-symbols mark the image positions (relative to G1) from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082967 id=\"98082967\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Time-delays</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">From the lens models, we can also give some forecasts on the expected delays between the arrival times <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ7\" content-id=\"equ7\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nt_{i} = \\frac{(1+z_{\\text{l}})D_{l}D_{s}}{\\mathrm{c}D_{ls}}\\left[\\frac{1}{2}\\left|\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im,i}-\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s}\\right|^{2}-\\Phi \\right]\\, ,\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div>where the projected potential \u03a6 is analytic in all models chosen.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Their values are approximately the same across different models, albeit with \u224820 \u2009d differences, and the ordering is always the same: the first image is A, followed by B, C shortly after, and finally D. The ordering is general and does not depend on whether a perturber is included in the model, being determined by the configuration of critical points (e.g. Saha &amp; Williams\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). Within the SIS+XS+G2 model, we have \u0394<em>t</em>(<em>AB</em>)\u00a0=\u00a085\u2009d, \u0394<em>t</em>(<em>BC</em>)\u00a0=\u00a06\u2009d, and \u0394<em>t</em>(<em>BD</em>)\u00a0=\u00a029\u2009d, where \u0394<em>t</em>(<em>i, j</em>)\u00a0=\u00a0<em>t<sub>j</sub></em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>t<sub>i</sub></em> is positive when the arrival-time of image <em>i</em> is shorter than that of image <em>j</em>. The quoted values have large uncertainties, due to the wide degeneracies in the lens models, and their marginalized posterior is offset from the values from the best-fitting model. Models with free perturbers have a more symmetric posterior, and smaller uncertainties in the predicted time-delays. Delays like these are ideal for ground based monitoring, because they are long enough to yield 1\u20133\u2009per\u2009cent precision with daily cadence, yet short enough that one or two observing seasons are sufficient. The delays predicted by models with free perturbers are in coarse agreement with those accurately measured by an ongoing, high-cadence 2.2m-WFI monitoring campaign (Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). However, the current data and models are not sufficient to allow for a proper comparison, primarily because of long-term microlensing effects and uncertainties in the lens potential.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98082970 id=\"98082970\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have modelled J0408\u22125354 to obtain the photometry of its individual components, the stellar mass of the main lens galaxy and lens parameters for a choice of plausible models. The predicted time-delays and image configuration make this system amenable to follow-up for time-delay cosmography, as well as for studies of the quasar host near the central engine and substructure near the quasar images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With the current data quality, there are vast degeneracies in the lens model parameters, which however can be easily relieved with high-resolution imaging data. This will also help locate the perturber G2 responsible for the reddening <em>and</em> dimming of image C. The occurrence of both cases would not be uncommon, as seen e.g. for the lens B1608+656 (Myers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). A direct measurement of the lens velocity dispersion, together with the recently measured time-delays (Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), would yield a direct measurement of the angular-diameter distance to the lens via <em>D<sub>l</sub></em>\u221dc<sup>3</sup>\u0394<em>t</em>/\u03c3<sup>2</sup> (see Paraficz &amp; Hjorth\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, for a general discussion).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082973 id=\"98082973\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 System configuration</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">J0408\u22125354 consists of three blue point-like images of the source quasar at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.375, and two redder components of which G1, the main lens, is at <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.597, whereas the nature of G2/C is unclear, given its colours and the significant contamination from spectra of other components (Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We have modelled this system as a superposition of an extended galaxy (G1) plus four compact sources A, B, D, G2/C and obtained deconvolved SEDs. In particular, the SED of G1 suggests a stellar mass <em>M</em><sub>\u22c6</sub> \u2248 3.2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> for the lens, within \u22480.4 dex uncertainty. There is a degree of systematic uncertainty in the positions and fluxes of B and G2/C, given their proximity and the fact that B is more than a magnitude brighter than G2/C in bluer bands. Some faint residuals are given by PSF mismatch on pixel scales, regardless of the choice of PSF. The WFI images with best seeing, once deconvolved, show what could be an additional ring with radius <em>R</em> \u2248 1.6\u2009arcsec, which is appreciably smaller than that inferred from lens models based on the positions of images A,B,D (as summarized below). If it corresponds to a second source, it can map to a unique location only if it lies at a redshift between those of quasar and deflector.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082975 id=\"98082975\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Lens model properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The positions of images A, B, D relative to G1 have been used to explore lens models of J0408\u22125354. Models with one main lens, adopted as SIE or SIS plus external shear, predict an Einstein radius \u22481.9\u2009arcsec and a lens p.a. \u2248 30\u2009deg East of North, or equivalent quadrupole contributions from \u03b3<sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.1 shear. Both models, while successful at reproducing the positions of images A, B, D, would predict a saddle-point image where G2/C lies, and about as bright as image B, which is not observed even in band Y or after differential extinction corrections. Models with a small perturber at the location of G2 reproduce the same image positions, but are able to suppress image C by about a magnitude even before dust is accounted for. The dust-corrected and delay-corrected flux ratios, as well as the images measured from the DES cutouts, are well reproduced by two small perturbers near the saddle-points.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The projected mass within the Einstein radius is <em>M<sub>p</sub></em>(<em>R</em><sub>E</sub>) \u2248 6\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>, about twice the stellar mass estimated from the SED of G1. A proper evaluation of the dark matter fraction in the lens, however, would require a measurement of the effective radius of G1. When the perturber has non-null Einstein radius, its enclosed mass is <em>M<sub>p</sub></em>(<em>G</em>2) \u2248 1.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup><em>M</em><sub>\u22c6</sub>. The contribution of a small galaxy with magnitudes <em>m</em>(<em>G</em>2)\u00a0=\u00a0<em>m</em>(<em>G</em>1)\u00a0\u2212\u00a02.5log<sub>10</sub>(<em>M<sub>p</sub></em>(<em>G</em>2)/<em>M<sub>p</sub></em>(<em>G</em>1)) is barely noticeable in <em>gri</em> bands. It can be well reproduced by reddening and offsetting the SED of image B by \u22480.8\u2009mag, and makes the <em>zY</em>-band magnitudes of image G2/C in complete agreement with the values measured from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> (black line in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The estimated time-delays between images A,B,D (from lens models with free perturbers) are somewhat in agreement with what is measured by Courbin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) through a 2.2m-WFI dedicated monitoring campaign. Still, given the uncertainties on image positions and few constraints, the derived uncertainties are appreciable and higher-resolution imaging data will be required to tighten the model-predicted uncertainties on the delays.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If indeed two sources are present at different redshift, J0408\u22125354 can also be used to measure Dark Energy cosmological parameters via the ratio of distance ratios <em>D<sub>s</sub></em>/<em>D<sub>ls</sub></em> to the different sources (e.g. Paczynski &amp; Gorski\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1981</a>; Soucail, Kneib &amp; Golse\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Collett et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), besides time-delay cosmography to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>. The only other system with time delays and multiple source-planes that is known and studied to date is the galaxy cluster MACSJ1149.5+2223 (Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082980 id=\"98082980\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Relevance of J0408\u22125354 for lens searches</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The photometry and configuration of J0408\u22125354 make it an interesting testbed for different techniques of lensed quasar candidate selection. These, in turn, have implications for substructure studies, as the composition of lens-selected or source-selected samples affects the sensitivity to substructure, especially for lens searches that are tailored on simple lenses or on systems dominated by \u2018isolated\u2019 quasar SEDs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Like the serendipitous quad of More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), J0408\u22125354 was originally found by visual inspection of objects selected solely on <em>gri</em> survey properties, instead of relying on hybrid infrared \u2018excess\u2019 colours (Warren, Hewett &amp; Foltz\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) that have been used to target quasars (Maddox &amp; Hewett\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Maddox et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Peters et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) or lenses (Ofek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) and applied in other lens searches in DES (Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). After the initial discovery via the blue-near-red search of Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), different teams have examined their own search methods. Here we provide a summary of the different findings.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=98082983 id=\"98082983\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-1>4.3.1 Cutout classification: CHITAH</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"small-caps\">CHITAH</span> (Chan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) examines the image cutouts of objects to detect at least two blue compact sources and a red galaxy, evaluating how plausible the configuration is as a strong lens via the corresponding source-plane \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. This approach relies on the requirement that the blue images have very similar SEDs, distinct from the lens SED.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">When applied to the <em>grizY</em> cutouts of J0408\u22125354, it did not flag this system as a possible quad since the fourth image G2/C is significantly redder than the others. However, based on A, B and G1, it did classify this system as a possible double. These findings suggest that pixel-based automatic recognition, such as <span class=\"small-caps\">CHITAH</span> or <span class=\"small-caps\">LensTractor</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> could be made more flexible by accounting for possible SED variations of the predicted images.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=98082986 id=\"98082986\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3-2>4.3.2 Target selection: data mining</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The first technique used to select lensed quasars in the DES relied upon Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) trained on SDSS <em>griz</em> and WISE (Wright et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) <em>W</em>1, <em>W</em>2 bands of four main classes of objects (Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>). Despite the success of the first discovery results (Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>), further improvements could be made for wider application to DES, as discussed in Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">B</a>. With these new ANNs, J0408\u22125354 was automatically flagged as an extended quasar with <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a01.75, one of the two classes (besides \u2018lens\u2019) to be retained for visual inspection.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup> Despite the improvement in the ANNs and the <em>blind</em> re-discovery of J0408\u22125354, there is considerable scatter in the SDSS-DES translated magnitudes, which can cause some interesting objects to slip out of the selection boundaries (and false positives to leak in). The outlier selection method (Agnello\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), in which J0408\u22125354 is rediscovered as a &gt;3\u03c3 outlier among quasars and with low probability to be a galaxy, is somewhat immune from this issue, as are Population Mixture classifications (Williams et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98082988 id=\"98082988\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">J0408\u22125354 has an interesting fold-like image configuration, with three well-separated images (A,B,D) and a fourth one (C) in a merging pair with the brightest image (B). Besides the three, clearly identifiable blue images of the source quasar, a fourth component G2/C is fainter than simple lens-model predictions and appreciably red. While image B is already redder than the farthest image A, with \u0394(<em>Y</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>r</em>) \u2248 0.65 compatible with a simple (Cardelli et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>) reddening law with <em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00.3, image G2/C is further reddened (additional <em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00.3) and also requires a grey dimming of \u22480.8\u2009mag in every band.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A small perturber (<em>R</em><sub>E, p</sub> \u2248 0.2\u2009arcsec, <em>M<sub>p</sub></em> \u2248 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>) near the location of G2/C explains both the needed reddening and dimming over the whole <em>grizY</em> range. The data on positions and (dust-corrected, delay-corrected) flux ratios allow for two perturbers near the saddle-point images C and D, albeit with very uncertain masses (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) due to the current scarcity of constraints.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The image separation makes this system particularly apt to time-delay measurements. The B\u2013A delay \u2248120\u2013140 \u2009d predicted by the full models (SIE+XS+pert.) is in good agreement with the results of a dedicated 2.2m-WFI monitoring campaign (Bonvin et al. 2017, in preparation). The lens mass within the Einstein radius <em>R</em><sub>E</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.73\u2009arcsec is <em>M<sub>p</sub></em> \u2248 (6.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.0)\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>, about twice the stellar mass <em>M</em><sub>\u22c6</sub> \u2248 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> of the main galaxy G1.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The chromaticity and morphology of J0408\u22125354 mean that different search techniques, while successfully flagging it as a lens candidate, are triggered by different features. Also, the peculiar colours and configuration of the quasar images are a powerful reminder that automated search techniques should be flexible enough to encompass these systems, in view of homogeneous lens-selected or source-selected samples for follow-up science. Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) estimated 1146 quasar lenses within a depth of <em>i</em>\u00a0=\u00a023.6 in the 5000 deg<sup>2</sup> final DES footprint, of which 14percent are quads. Past and ongoing lens searches show that a suite of complementary techniques are needed to maximize the number of detected lenses, especially at magnitudes fainter than <em>i</em> \u2248 19.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The composition of J0408\u22125354, with a primary (massive) lens and a small perturber and a merging image-pair, make it both an interesting system for follow-up and a rather peculiar system to model. Spectroscopic and high-resolution imaging observations would enable more accurate models, both for cosmography and for substructure studies, and a highly magnified view of the source quasar and its host.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98082994 id=\"98082994\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgements</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">AA and TT acknowledge support by the Packard Foundations through a Packard Research Fellowship and by the National Science Foundation through grant AST-1450141.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper was written as part of the STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) collaboration, a broad external collaboration of the Dark Energy Survey, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://strides.astro.ucla.edu\" target=\"_blank\">http://strides.astro.ucla.edu</a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We are grateful to the anonymous referee for a \u2018fresh\u2019 and thorough reading of the paper, which helped clarify several points.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the DOE and NSF(USA), MISE(Spain), STFC(UK), HEFCE(UK). NCSA(UIUC), KICP(U. Chicago), CCAPP(Ohio State), MIFPA(Texas A&amp;M), CNPQ, FAPERJ, FINEP (Brazil), MINECO(Spain), DFG(Germany) and the Collaborating Institutions in the Dark Energy Survey. The Collaborating Institutions are Argonne Lab, UC Santa Cruz, University of Cambridge, CIEMAT-Madrid, University of Chicago, University College London, DES-Brazil Consortium, University of Edinburgh, ETH Z\u00fcrich, Fermilab, University of Illinois, ICE (IEEC-CSIC), IFAE Barcelona, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, LMU M\u00fcnchen and the associated Excellence Cluster Universe, University of Michigan, NOAO, University of Nottingham, Ohio State University, University of Pennsylvania, University of Portsmouth, SLAC National Lab, Stanford University, University of Sussex, and Texas A&amp;M University. The DES Data Management System is supported by the NSF under Grant Number AST-1138766. The DES participants from Spanish institutions are partially supported by MINECO under grants AYA2012-39559, ESP2013-48274, FPA2013-47986 and Centro de Excelencia Severo Ochoa SEV-2012-0234. Research leading to these results has received funding from the ERC under the EU\u2019s 7<sup>th</sup> Framework Programme including grants ERC 240672, 291329 and 306478.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The DES data processing and calibration system is described by Bertin (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), Mohr et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and references therein; its implementation on the Y1A1 release is described by Drlica-Wagner et\u00a0al. (2017, in preparation).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Available at: <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://w.astro.berkeley.edu/~mariska/FAST.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://w.astro.berkeley.edu/~mariska/FAST.html</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The numerical prefactors in the second equalities are specific to the redshifts <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>, <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> of source and deflector in this particular case.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We should caution the reader that shear angles obtained in these models depend on the convention chosen for the orientation and on how to write the shear contribution in equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>). With this convention, the shear direction corresponds to mass overdensities perpendicular to it. Different choices can yield to shear angles perpendicular to these, i.e. aligned with the p.a. of G1.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">With <em>R<sub>V</sub></em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1 and <em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00.3, blueshifting the DES wavebands to the lens rest frame.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/davidwhogg/LensTractor\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/davidwhogg/LensTractor</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn7\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn7\" class=\"end-note-link\">7</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">In particular, the blend D+G1 with catalogue ID = 3070264166, RA = 62.0904688061, DEC = \u221253.8996413857</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn8\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn8\" class=\"end-note-link\">8</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We refer to Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>) for the definition of \u2018blue and extended\u2019 in this case.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98083009 id=\"98083009\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Wright</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">E. L.</div></span> et al.\u00a0</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">AJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">140</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1868</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-6256/140/6/1868\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-6256%2F140%2F6%2F1868\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98083012 id=\"98083012\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>APPENDIX A: LENS MODELLING SPECIFICS</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Regardless of the model specifics, all images must map to the same source-position. For each choice of the lens model parameters, a source at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_s$|</span> in the source plane corresponds to images <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_i$|</span> in the image plane, and the goodness of fit can be described by the image-plane \u03c7<sup>2</sup><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ8\" content-id=\"equ8\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\chi ^{2}_{ip} = \\sum _{i = 1}^{3}\\frac{\\left|\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{i}-\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im,i}\\right|^{2}}{\\delta ^{2}_{i}} = \\sum _{i = 1}^{3}\\frac{\\left|\\mathbf {A}_{i}(\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_s-\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s,i})\\right|^{2}}{\\delta ^{2}_{i}}\\, ,\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(A1)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im,i}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s,i}$|</span> are the measured image-positions and their model-predicted source-plane positions for images A,B,D, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathbf {A}_{i} = \\partial \\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im,i}/\\partial \\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s,i}$|</span> is the magnification tensor around each image and \u03b4<sub><em>i</em></sub> is the positional uncertainty on image <em>i</em>. The second equality relies on the fact that, near a reasonable lens solution, we can linearize the lens equation around the measured image positions. Then, within this approach, the best-fitting source-position and corresponding image-plane \u03c7<sup>2</sup> and image-positions can be found by straightforward linear operations. Its validity has been tested extensively by Oguri (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Based on those functional tests and ours, the lens models are accurate provided one iterates \u224830\u00a0times between the linearized best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_s$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im,i}$|\u2060</span>, ensuring that all model image-positions are re-mapped to the same source-point.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Writing the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> as above relies on a Gaussian distribution of the measured image positions, with isotropic positional uncertainties, and is equivalent to drawing image positions with infinite precision from Gaussians <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {G}(\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im,i},\\delta _{i})$|\u2060</span>, considering (for each choice) a highly-penalized image-plane <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2 = p\\chi ^{2}_{ip,1}$|</span> in the lens model with <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ9\" content-id=\"equ9\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\chi ^{2}_{ip,1} = \\sum _{i = 1}^{3}\\left|\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{i}-\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im,i}\\right|^{2}\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(A2)</span></div>and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p\\gg \\delta ^{-2}_{i}$|\u2060</span>. This allows us to generalize the lens model likelihood to image configurations that do not have isotropic and Gaussian uncertainties. In particular, we can draw the relative displacements of G1, B and D with respect to image A as given by the likelihood explored in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, which we call <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}_{\\text{SED}}$|\u2060</span>. At very high values of <em>p</em>, the only parameter combinations that are explored are those that correspond to all image positions mapping back to the same source position, because other configurations are heavily penalized.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Another hypothesis underlying this approach is that the measured image position uncertainties are simply given by the extraction of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, so that each image carries a weight proportional to its (squared) magnification in the \u03c7<sup>2</sup>. This does not account for systematic uncertainties in the image positions given by the proximity of different objects and PSF mismatch. This problem is evident for the brightest image B, which would instead carry the highest weight in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^{2}_{im}$|\u2060</span>. We then opt for a penalized source-plane \u03c7<sup>2</sup> of the form <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ10\" content-id=\"equ10\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\chi ^{2}_{sp}\\ = \\ p\\sum _{j = 1}^{3}\\left|\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s,j}-\\langle \\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s}\\rangle \\right|^{2}\\, ,\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(A3)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s}\\rangle = (\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s,\\text{A}}+\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s,\\text{B}}+\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s,\\text{C}})/3$|</span> for each choice of the model parameters, and consider the lens-model likelihood as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ11\" content-id=\"equ11\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\mathcal {L}\\ \\propto \\ \\mathcal {L}_{\\text{SED}}(\\boldsymbol{\\theta })\\times \\rm {e}^{-\\chi ^{2}_{sp}/2}\\, .\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(A4)</span></div>The penalty parameter <em>p</em> is gradually increased, until all possible models are effectively producing images originating from the same source-position, within milli-arcsecond tolerance, and the model uncertainties are driven by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}_{\\text{SED}}$|\u2060</span>.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98083016 id=\"98083016\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>APPENDIX B: MINING ACROSS SURVEYS</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The original implementation of ANNs was based upon SDSS data and four main classes of objects. In order to be more widely applicable to DES, it was improved in three ways: (i) more object classes, including multiple redshift intervals for the \u2018quasar\u2019 class to distinguish low-redshift contaminants from higher-redshift objects; (ii) less restrictive colour-cuts, that would otherwise exclude known lenses with higher <em>g</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>i</em> or lower <em>W</em>1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>W</em>2; and (iii) accounting for the differences in photometry between SDSS and DES via a cross-calibration valid for blue extended objects.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">8</a></sup> The best-fitting regressions have <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ12\" content-id=\"equ12\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\ng_{\\rm des} &amp;=&amp; g_{\\rm sdss}+0.05,\\ \\ r_{\\rm des}\\ = \\ r_{\\rm sdss}+0.088,\\nonumber \\\\\r\ni_{\\rm des} &amp;=&amp; i_{\\rm sdss}+0.112,\\ \\ z_{\\rm des}\\ = \\ z_{\\rm sdss}+0.159,\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(B1)</span></div>for the <span class=\"monospace\">psf</span> magnitudes, and <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ13\" content-id=\"equ13\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\nonumber g_{\\rm des} &amp;=&amp; g_{\\rm sdss}+0.165-0.092(g_{\\rm des}-r_{\\rm des}-0.4)\\\\\r\n\\nonumber r_{\\rm des} &amp;=&amp; r_{\\rm sdss}+0.118-0.215(g_{\\rm des}-r_{\\rm des}-0.4)\\\\\r\n\\nonumber&amp;&amp; \\quad i_{\\rm des} = i_{\\rm sdss}+0.04-0.2(i_{\\rm des}-z_{\\rm des})\\\\\r\nz_{\\rm des} &amp;=&amp; z_{\\rm sdss}+0.078-0.044(z_{\\rm des}-Y_{\\rm des}-0.17)\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(B2)</span></div>for the <span class=\"monospace\">model</span> magnitudes. There is considerable scatter (0.11\u20130.18\u2009mag) in the translated magnitudes, given by the extendedness of the objects and different depth and image quality between SDSS and DES. This means that interesting candidates (resp. contaminants) can leak out of (resp. within) the hyperplanes defining class boundaries as identified by the ANN classification.</div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n<div class=\"copyright copyright-statement\">\u00a9 2017 The Authors Published by Oxford        <div class=\"article-cited-link-wrap crossref-citedby\">\r\n                <a href='https://academic.oup.com/mnras/crossref-citedby/4107762'>Crossref</a>\r\n            </div>\r\n class=\"articleListNewAndPopularCombinedView\">\r\n            <li>\r\n                <h3>\r\n                    <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode active\" data-mode=\"MostRecent\">Latest</a>\r\n                </h3>\r\n            </li>\r\n            <li>\r\n                <h3>\r\n                    <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode \" data-mode=\"MostRead\">Most Read</a>\r\n                </h3>\r\n            </li>\r\n            <li>\r\n                <h3>\r\n                    <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode \" data-mode=\"MostCited\">Most Cited</a>\r\n                </h3>\r\n            </li>\r\n    </ul>\r\n        <section class=\"articleListNewPopContent articleListNewAndPopular-ContentView-MostRecent hasContent\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"newPopularList-Article_RightRailB0Article_RightRail_ArticleNewPopularCombined\" class=\"fb\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-layout widget-layout--vert\">\r\n            <div class=\"widget-columns widget-col-1\">\r\n                    <div class=\"col\">\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3878\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3878/6041709?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nMagnetic field and chromospheric activity evolution of HD 75332: a rapid magnetic cycle in an F star without a hot Jupiter    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3914\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3914/6041708?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nDynamical dark energy after Planck CMB final release and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> tension    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3879\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3879/6041707?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nThe Hierarchical Structure of Galactic Haloes: Classification and characterisation with <sc>Halo-OPTICS</sc>    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3900\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3900/6041706?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nThe Three Hundred Project: quest of clusters of galaxies morphology and dynamical state through Zernike polynomials    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3790\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3790/6041705?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nThe Correlation Between Impact Crater Ages and Chronostratigraphic Boundary Dates    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017MNRAS.472.4038A", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "We present detailed modelling of the recently discovered, quadruply lensed quasar J0408-5354, with the aim of interpreting its remarkable configuration: besides three quasar images (A,B,D) around the main deflector (G1), a fourth image (C) is significantly reddened and dimmed by a perturber (G2) which is not detected in the Dark Energy Survey imaging data. From lens models incorporating (dust-corrected) flux ratios, we find a perturber Einstein radius 0.04 arcsec \u2272 R<SUB>E, G2</SUB> \u2272 0.2 arcsec and enclosed mass M<SUB>p</SUB>(R<SUB>E, G2</SUB>) \u2272 1.0 \u00d7 10<SUP>10</SUP> M<SUB>\u2609</SUB>. The main deflector has stellar mass log _{10}(M_{\\star }/M_{\u2609})=11.49^{+0.46}_{-0.32}, a projected mass M<SUB>p</SUB>(R<SUB>E, G1</SUB>) \u2248 6 \u00d7 10<SUP>11</SUP> M<SUB>\u2609</SUB> within its Einstein radius R<SUB>E, G1</SUB> = (1.85 \u00b1 0.15) arcsec and predicted velocity dispersion 267-280 km s<SUP>-1</SUP>. Follow-up images from a companion monitoring campaign show additional components, including a candidate second source at a redshift between the quasar and G1. Models with free perturbers, and dust-corrected and delay-corrected flux ratios, are also explored. The predicted time-delays (\u2206t<SUB>AB</SUB> = (135.0 \u00b1 12.6) d, \u2206t<SUB>BD</SUB> = (21.0 \u00b1 3.5) d) roughly agree with those measured, but better imaging is required for proper modelling and comparison. We also discuss some lessons learnt from J0408-5354 on lensed quasar finding strategies, due to its chromaticity and morphology.", "start_page": "4038", "authors": ["Agnello, A.", "Lin, H.", "Buckley-Geer, L.", "Treu, T.", "Bonvin, V.", "Courbin, F.", "Lemon, C.", "Morishita, T.", "Amara, A.", "Auger, M. \">Alerts</a>\r\n                \r\n            </li>\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\" id=\"site-menu-item-1493345\">\r\n                <a href=\"/mnras/#\" $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f472%2f4%2f4038%2f4107762\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div
