</div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98082915 id=\"98082915\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present detailed modelling of the recently discovered, quadruply lensed quasar J0408\u22125354, with the aim of interpreting its remarkable configuration: besides three quasar images (A,B,D) around the main deflector (G1), a fourth image (C) is significantly reddened and dimmed by a perturber (G2) which is not detected in the Dark Energy Survey imaging data. From lens models incorporating (dust-corrected) flux ratios, we find a perturber Einstein radius 0.04\u2009arcsec \u2272 <em>R</em><sub>E, G2</sub> \u2272 0.2\u2009arcsec and enclosed mass <em>M<sub>p</sub></em>(<em>R</em><sub>E, G2</sub>) \u2272 1.0\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>10</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The main deflector has stellar mass <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10}(M_{\\star }/\\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }})=11.49^{+0.46}_{-0.32}$|\u2060</span>, a projected mass <em>M<sub>p</sub></em>(<em>R</em><sub>E, G1</sub>) \u2248 6\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> within its Einstein radius <em>R</em><sub>E, G1</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(1.85\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15)\u2009arcsec and predicted velocity dispersion 267\u2013280\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Follow-up images from a companion monitoring campaign show additional components, including a candidate second source at a redshift between the quasar and G1. Models with free perturbers, and dust-corrected and delay-corrected flux ratios, are also explored. The predicted time-delays (\u0394<em>t</em><sub>AB</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(135.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a012.6)\u2009d, \u0394<em>t</em><sub>BD</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(21.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.5)\u2009d) roughly agree with those measured, but better imaging is required for proper modelling and comparison. We also discuss some lessons learnt from J0408\u22125354\u2009 on lensed quasar finding strategies, due to its chromaticity and morphology.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: image processing&quot;\">techniques: image processing</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"catalogues\">catalogues</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98082917 id=\"98082917\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strongly lensed quasars are interesting astrophysical objects for diverse purposes (Courbin, Saha &amp; Schechter\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). The morphology of the multiple images, accompanied by arcs or rings tracing the lensed host galaxy, enables the description of the mass profile of the lens/deflector galaxy, which typically sits at redshifts <em>z</em><sub>l</sub> \u2248 0.5\u20131 (e.g. Oguri, Rusu &amp; Falco\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Thanks to magnification, the source can be superresolved, well beyond what is possible for unlensed distant quasars. Astrometric and flux ratio \u2018anomalies\u2019 among the multiple images are signatures of luminous and/or dark substructure surrounding the lens (Dalal &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Nierenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), as well as faint features such as extended discs or isophotal twist, boxiness or disciness (M\u00f6ller, Hewett &amp; Blain <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gilman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Hsueh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). When the source luminosity varies over time, the time delay between different images can be measured (e.g. Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Tewes, Courbin &amp; Meylan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and used to measure cosmological distances (as originally envisioned by Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>, for lensed supernovae) and hence the expansion rate of the Universe, yielding low-redshift (<em>z</em><sub>l</sub>) constraints on cosmological parameters that are independent of local distance-scale calibrations (cf. Treu &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, and references therein).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image configuration has a central role for these studies. Systems with four images of the source quasar (hereafter <em>quads</em>) provide more information on the mass profiles of the deflector. In contrast, systems with two well-separated images (or <em>doubles</em>) can generally be more easily monitored for time variability with ground-based long-cadence observations, since fewer point sources must be de-blended within the same region. Systems in a <em>fold</em> configuration, where two of the quasar images are close to one another, are an interesting transition case: while enabling a robust lens mass reconstruction (see Ding et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, for a discussion of specific systems), they are also easier to follow up for time delays than other configurations with comparable Einstein radii. In particular, in a fold configuration the source lies close to the caustic separating the double and quad regimes, with a <em>merging pair</em> of two of the images, thereby giving a highly stretched view of the quasar host near its centre (More et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field surveys offer a significant opportunity to discover new systems with suitable configuration, to be followed up for ancillary data. In particular, the Dark Energy Survey (hereafter DES: S\u00e1nchez &amp; DES Collaboration\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) has opened a new window for lens searches in the Southern hemisphere, thanks to a combination of large footprint, depth and good image quality of the Dark Energy Camera (Flaugher et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we detail the first models of a new quasar lens, J0408\u22125354 (RA = 62.091333, DEC = \u221253.900266). This lens was discovered by Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) in the Y1A1 release of DES (Diehl et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, Drlica-Wagner et\u00a0al. 2017, in preparation), through a visual inspection of blue objects near red galaxies. Its multiband images show four compact sources, compatible with being point-like, given the DES point-spread-function (PSF), around a luminous red galaxy, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. A spectroscopic confirmation campaign (Lin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) shows that the three bright, blue point sources are images of the same source quasar at redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.375, with absorption features at <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.597 that can be attributed to the lens galaxy. The fourth compact source to the South-West (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) is redder than the other confirmed quasar images. Detailed modelling is required to determine whether the anomalous colour is given by dust extinction, microlensing or an additional red galaxy along the line of sight.</p>                        <a id=\"98082922\" scrollto-destination=\"98082922\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=VL58qwWw0Slsj1xL3uQWB--I3KBYTjeZP1a-TpGb8q~t3ZJzH6~pT~J5iAR9ZfMpB5HPkqK7RCS1KPLAWXIhSGXtzxoK0f0J6hkoxl93mzl7~YADH8ZTC2rKBGsqsQgrRyujG~68paWtAs5HFpPl4o8NK2SGskiiqTjvyyiIKlPKR1l1mgi3BCJUc~HaFR5H~DWAkqKdrciszjopgBv9uCJXsz6LqGu7x2Q8XJc~QiFODGDEge-d2z9Ff5AzRZ9i7761nBd3wUyvTo7xJXm-k4i48Kg6HoQZH~JDr2oz5KqFRglR46VtZ4I1jt875gEuH6hHwIagRFXWPsFPWqpw4w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multiband images of J0408\u22125354 in grizY, from DES single-epoch data with best image quality, plus colour-composites (gri, riz, izY) in the last three columns. The data are shown in the first line with overlaid best-fitting positions, the best-fitting model (as detailed in Section\u00a02) in the second line and the residuals in the third line. An extra source between A and D is visible in the residuals, indicated as \u2018G3\u2019 in Fig.\u00a02. Most of the residuals, besides G3, are due to PSF mismatch (around image A) and by blending of B and G2/C. North is up and East is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082922/stx2242fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082922\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=pIiewQ9uR6w4yKoYI-5-nX0qBoNkH1fsn57jQ58AD1sNj2eSl3coWOVr1zrHTNnC-nVDsijxX-gY5M1x9omYUS21KFcmeUdBtmc3G6nnaEOakwSyuPJjf29KI47hagt~Vkzy1M55baRIPESXACo-kTDsPUZLbKDF7ZRBaK~mq5RHp~dLugMVISesid45Aa-EFR-kj6UWgatJoDM79v3LMncVvUnfekZLtYx0Th7osym7iIoGazrxKCPn2I5hVrDJaMfvUknHrMAg3JlvRS4LlAB59K5SiVkZZDD-gX7-tmLGsIwO7bdpcV3A8Mvz71QlhRJBH2LuDG0qX8uLha1pVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082922&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiband images of J0408\u22125354 in <em>grizY</em>, from DES single-epoch data with best image quality, plus colour-composites (<em>gri, riz, izY</em>) in the last three columns. The data are shown in the first line with overlaid best-fitting positions, the best-fitting model (as detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>) in the second line and the residuals in the third line. An extra source between A and D is visible in the residuals, indicated as \u2018G3\u2019 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Most of the residuals, besides G3, are due to PSF mismatch (around image A) and by blending of B and G2/C. North is up and East is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=VL58qwWw0Slsj1xL3uQWB--I3KBYTjeZP1a-TpGb8q~t3ZJzH6~pT~J5iAR9ZfMpB5HPkqK7RCS1KPLAWXIhSGXtzxoK0f0J6hkoxl93mzl7~YADH8ZTC2rKBGsqsQgrRyujG~68paWtAs5HFpPl4o8NK2SGskiiqTjvyyiIKlPKR1l1mgi3BCJUc~HaFR5H~DWAkqKdrciszjopgBv9uCJXsz6LqGu7x2Q8XJc~QiFODGDEge-d2z9Ff5AzRZ9i7761nBd3wUyvTo7xJXm-k4i48Kg6HoQZH~JDr2oz5KqFRglR46VtZ4I1jt875gEuH6hHwIagRFXWPsFPWqpw4w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multiband images of J0408\u22125354 in grizY, from DES single-epoch data with best image quality, plus colour-composites (gri, riz, izY) in the last three columns. The data are shown in the first line with overlaid best-fitting positions, the best-fitting model (as detailed in Section\u00a02) in the second line and the residuals in the third line. An extra source between A and D is visible in the residuals, indicated as \u2018G3\u2019 in Fig.\u00a02. Most of the residuals, besides G3, are due to PSF mismatch (around image A) and by blending of B and G2/C. North is up and East is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082922/stx2242fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082922\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=pIiewQ9uR6w4yKoYI-5-nX0qBoNkH1fsn57jQ58AD1sNj2eSl3coWOVr1zrHTNnC-nVDsijxX-gY5M1x9omYUS21KFcmeUdBtmc3G6nnaEOakwSyuPJjf29KI47hagt~Vkzy1M55baRIPESXACo-kTDsPUZLbKDF7ZRBaK~mq5RHp~dLugMVISesid45Aa-EFR-kj6UWgatJoDM79v3LMncVvUnfekZLtYx0Th7osym7iIoGazrxKCPn2I5hVrDJaMfvUknHrMAg3JlvRS4LlAB59K5SiVkZZDD-gX7-tmLGsIwO7bdpcV3A8Mvz71QlhRJBH2LuDG0qX8uLha1pVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082922&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiband images of J0408\u22125354 in <em>grizY</em>, from DES single-epoch data with best image quality, plus colour-composites (<em>gri, riz, izY</em>) in the last three columns. The data are shown in the first line with overlaid best-fitting positions, the best-fitting model (as detailed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>) in the second line and the residuals in the third line. An extra source between A and D is visible in the residuals, indicated as \u2018G3\u2019 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Most of the residuals, besides G3, are due to PSF mismatch (around image A) and by blending of B and G2/C. North is up and East is left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this follow-up paper, we aim to shed light on the lensing nature of J0408\u22125354, expanding upon the discovery paper. First, we model the DES images to obtain object positions and spectral-energy distributions (SEDs). The multiband SEDs of the point-sources can be used to quantify chromatic effects (such as microlensing or dust extinction), while the SED of the lens galaxy is used to estimate its stellar mass. The positions of deflector and images are used as inputs to gravitational lens models, whose results are then used to estimate the dark matter content of the lens and verify whether an additional galaxy, lying very close to the reddened compact source along the line of sight, is needed to reproduce the observed flux ratios. We will show that based on the data available so far, the most plausible interpretation of the system consists of a main deflector galaxy and a satellite producing four images of a background lens quasar. The satellite deflector is very well aligned with one of the images, suppressing its flux and contaminating its colours.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is structured as follows. In Section 2, we detail the multiband model results of the DES <em>grizY</em> images. A comparison of different lens models is given in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. We conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, including a discussion of the significance of J0408\u22125354 for different quasar lens searches, and briefly summarize in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. Whenever needed, a standard flat \u039bCDM cosmology is adopted with \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u2009km\u2009s<sup> \u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup> \u2212 1</sup>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98082925 id=\"98082925\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 SYSTEM CONFIGURATION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">J0408\u22125354 consists of point-like and extended objects (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, 0.263 arcsec px<sup>\u22121</sup>), which are blended in the DES segmentation maps. In order to obtain robust SED measurements, in this section we forward-model the <em>grizY</em> image cutouts as a superposition of objects, to recover robust magnitudes and relative positions with realistic uncertainties. The effective exposure time, as calculated by the reduction pipeline of single-epoch images is 540\u2009s (resp. 225\u2009s) for <em>griz</em> (resp. <em>Y</em>) cutouts. The on-target<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> PSF full width at half-maximum (FWHM) ranges from 0.56\u2009arcsec in <em>Y</em> band to 0.59\u2009arcsec in <em>g</em> band. We deployed two independent versions of our own codes to model the cutouts; likelihood is explored via MCMC, whence the maximum-a-posteriori values and their uncertainties are obtained.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Follow-up imaging observations have been conducted with the Wide-Field Imager (WFI) on the 2.2-m telescope in La Silla, to measure the time-delays between the light curves of different images (Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). A co-add and optimal deconvolution (following Magain et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) of the best-seeing images obtained so far, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, reveals a more complex structure: besides G1, A, B, G2/C and D, at least three additional \u2018blobs\u2019 are visible (G3,G4,G5), as well as a nearly complete Einstein ring with radius \u22481.6\u2009arcsec. Better data are needed to ascertain the nature of this ring and whether G3, G4, G5 are physically connected to it. The <em>R</em><sub>c</sub>-band image in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> has pixels of 0.12\u2009arcsec per side and point-sources with a FWHM=0.2\u2009arcsec, allowing to locate the position angle (p.a.) of G1 to \u224830\u2009deg E of N. We will discuss these aspects further in the following sections.</p>                        <a id=\"98082928\" scrollto-destination=\"98082928\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=P2dc0LXAoO5EQhTtcZaNDngtm7V0Xu9Fc-0y60zCZHTZc9eNuKkq6u44zGMrt9ScrHmFIgSFXbNgUWJdn~NpnLmqBBao7Ctl9b0n5LTYEsduMbe0x4gFLkY73duiBf1tY3~-msWW44KcBgGk5zdC1GQarp~1J3wscUkHHgzd8zts1VpZH4rG9wFM9edJuSs5tbs1~zvLvFHD6UD8cJS2nLVoX01g~Ljzr5WhcRXVFNVTJjhTN8T14C6k2JMl4i5102LgK59-spWT3TFBIr~zt6cwzLasFLHaD0Zs1saWmzRTJ5OyN6dTsI80ZUj9xpqjM4ZUlDDWbpa-MZAEaUTVMw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"WFI Rc-band image of J0408\u22125354 after co-add and deconvolution of the best-seeing images. The central lens galaxy is G1. Image A, farther from G1, is the first to reach the observer, followed by image B, C and D; lens models will need a perturber G2 near the location of image C (see Section 3); three additional blobs are visible, marked by blue circles and denoted as G3,G4,G5. G3 sits on a nearly complete ring of radius \u22481.6\u2009arcsec, indicated by the blue arrow.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082928/stx2242fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082928\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=5Igf--W39y2xFKGnTzmsK5N2z17cGFacBcJJY4HcWM1eIPJsw0hYs-UE6PxqcfzWfEZYBR~d0KMwjGWP7qD5ARtCy75cK2D6c5Kb0pCmwWaOtlLxQspKZ3zJu7UrmIhsmDMF6c-9ibkcpnHeUfSGDAfYV1Keov2oCaxtrqrmZEulotBujbbG487Gw2aLrkEAlZCVwT0AprIIt83Tr4tibFRmSGJdZk6vdJTi5iTDk7Bhe~qg2-gBEuDMUcDoeApf6vwzOkLC8nHtwKsIo7CfMUMkvO07tOz4gtw-WfhcvmZAjOnHzVRJx2NcZU1D4CldlsToA6px3~ja7MeJVMkhNQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082928&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">WFI <em>R</em><sub>c</sub>-band image of J0408\u22125354 after co-add and deconvolution of the best-seeing images. The central lens galaxy is <em>G</em>1. Image <em>A</em>, farther from <em>G</em>1, is the first to reach the observer, followed by image <em>B</em>, C and <em>D</em>; lens models will need a perturber G2 near the location of image C (see Section 3); three additional blobs are visible, marked by blue circles and denoted as G3,G4,G5. G3 sits on a nearly complete ring of radius \u22481.6\u2009arcsec, indicated by the blue arrow.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=P2dc0LXAoO5EQhTtcZaNDngtm7V0Xu9Fc-0y60zCZHTZc9eNuKkq6u44zGMrt9ScrHmFIgSFXbNgUWJdn~NpnLmqBBao7Ctl9b0n5LTYEsduMbe0x4gFLkY73duiBf1tY3~-msWW44KcBgGk5zdC1GQarp~1J3wscUkHHgzd8zts1VpZH4rG9wFM9edJuSs5tbs1~zvLvFHD6UD8cJS2nLVoX01g~Ljzr5WhcRXVFNVTJjhTN8T14C6k2JMl4i5102LgK59-spWT3TFBIr~zt6cwzLasFLHaD0Zs1saWmzRTJ5OyN6dTsI80ZUj9xpqjM4ZUlDDWbpa-MZAEaUTVMw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"WFI Rc-band image of J0408\u22125354 after co-add and deconvolution of the best-seeing images. The central lens galaxy is G1. G3 sits on a nearly complete ring of radius \u22481.6\u2009arcsec, indicated by the blue arrow.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082928/stx2242fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082928\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=5Igf--W39y2xFKGnTzmsK5N2z17cGFacBcJJY4HcWM1eIPJsw0hYs-UE6PxqcfzWfEZYBR~d0KMwjGWP7qD5ARtCy75cK2D6c5Kb0pCmwWaOtlLxQspKZ3zJu7UrmIhsmDMF6c-9ibkcpnHeUfSGDAfYV1Keov2oCaxtrqrmZEulotBujbbG487Gw2aLrkEAlZCVwT0AprIIt83Tr4tibFRmSGJdZk6vdJTi5iTDk7Bhe~qg2-gBEuDMUcDoeApf6vwzOkLC8nHtwKsIo7CfMUMkvO07tOz4gtw-WfhcvmZAjOnHzVRJx2NcZU1D4CldlsToA6px3~ja7MeJVMkhNQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082928&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">WFI <em>R</em><sub>c</sub>-band image of J0408\u22125354 after co-add and deconvolution of the best-seeing images. The central lens galaxy is <em>G</em>1. Image <em>A</em>, farther from <em>G</em>1, is the first to reach the observer, followed by image <em>B</em>, C and <em>D</em>; lens models will need a perturber G2 near the location of image C (see Section 3); three additional blobs are visible, marked by blue circles and denoted as G3,G4,G5. G3 sits on a nearly complete ring of radius \u22481.6\u2009arcsec, indicated by the blue arrow.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082929 id=\"98082929\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Image models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As illustrated in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, the system consists of a red galaxy (G1) surrounded by three blue point-like objects (A, B, D) and a redder and compact object (G2/C). As will be quantified in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, if the system is a genuine quad, then G2/C would be a saddle-point image \u2018C\u2019, merging with B in a fold-like configuration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Follow-up Gemini South spectra (programme ID GS-2017A-LP-5, PI E. Buckley-Geer) were taken in 2017 March and April, using the same setup as in Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), except that B and G2/C were targeted on the same slit. This slit setup permits spatial decomposition of the spectra and resolves the previous issue of contamination of the G2/C spectrum by light from the much brighter image B. The results confirm that G2/C has the same quasar emission lines as B and the other blue images, albeit with strong differential reddening (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"98082932\" scrollto-destination=\"98082932\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=hyH5MWmE4VRWhCgTaQT5lKfUoo6yDfOv0HhjK2Ig5yUl47EFlrM-6QRlnKU8H2EqiiPDRn0Ylwk7FewvXIdiPGrFAc1Ua~wfOWWzmG2x1Cc4rRTEhIgeR7pyw-z8-gTkVUYQ21npOVCIGONyJEVTAuirrIWvX9VfobTE0IH9abzjPQc5gtBP7f5OBmsM7ck4MsG~Iwy9lWHvWkI-OS0gUkhl7~FU9xgbofqcHJ0BXjMpds-L~x-QlLv-xFk7kCsqLoXhVxiawJAjrkfH2O48VnKymQtgViyLTyHM9-EcJxk6irK~X7k9wWAO1PI0HrxThTJsr6UQU1Hoeidgzy4SyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Follow-up spectra of images B and G2/C, obtained with a similar Gemini South setup as the discovery spectra of Lin et\u00a0al. (2017). Both images have the same emission lines, but G2/C is considerably dimmed and reddened with respect to image B.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082932/stx2242fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082932\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=IsyxHFmj0Dtqn1nvjvKRSpNSUPl0~l93s~N8w8tkb0N8bjmQ49R6bP1IJtzxXhslHyLRN~O~u5zfdC7KBQweef~bNBOkubgwrd7kg3cHfj86HUbypz8xM1Bw4cKyNTY9Hai1Mohqse1nOlzlEnb8r2KgLq9EE84qFNW6myn9aAho537j7DgIsDesmTZ31bm0sCELwY7GIkX2yy84GpsMthkLKnYItSnJbYQqA1fMeqYgaMK-YyZZrzKmu6xeel0RzxCR3YuUqrNjn68y-z5l2xtA6UjKhkXCt7LMTokOT8C3nwvFzycJZkUWjwamQrDVPnpeI9sdlhcvKxOLDympuA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082932&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Follow-up spectra of images B and G2/C, obtained with a similar Gemini South setup as the discovery spectra of Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Both images have the same emission lines, but G2/C is considerably dimmed and reddened with respect to image B.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=hyH5MWmE4VRWhCgTaQT5lKfUoo6yDfOv0HhjK2Ig5yUl47EFlrM-6QRlnKU8H2EqiiPDRn0Ylwk7FewvXIdiPGrFAc1Ua~wfOWWzmG2x1Cc4rRTEhIgeR7pyw-z8-gTkVUYQ21npOVCIGONyJEVTAuirrIWvX9VfobTE0IH9abzjPQc5gtBP7f5OBmsM7ck4MsG~Iwy9lWHvWkI-OS0gUkhl7~FU9xgbofqcHJ0BXjMpds-L~x-QlLv-xFk7kCsqLoXhVxiawJAjrkfH2O48VnKymQtgViyLTyHM9-EcJxk6irK~X7k9wWAO1PI0HrxThTJsr6UQU1Hoeidgzy4SyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Follow-up spectra of images B and G2/C, obtained with a similar Gemini South setup as the discovery spectra of Lin et\u00a0al. (2017). Both images have the same emission lines, but G2/C is considerably dimmed and reddened with respect to image B.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082932/stx2242fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082932\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=IsyxHFmj0Dtqn1nvjvKRSpNSUPl0~l93s~N8w8tkb0N8bjmQ49R6bP1IJtzxXhslHyLRN~O~u5zfdC7KBQweef~bNBOkubgwrd7kg3cHfj86HUbypz8xM1Bw4cKyNTY9Hai1Mohqse1nOlzlEnb8r2KgLq9EE84qFNW6myn9aAho537j7DgIsDesmTZ31bm0sCELwY7GIkX2yy84GpsMthkLKnYItSnJbYQqA1fMeqYgaMK-YyZZrzKmu6xeel0RzxCR3YuUqrNjn68y-z5l2xtA6UjKhkXCt7LMTokOT8C3nwvFzycJZkUWjwamQrDVPnpeI9sdlhcvKxOLDympuA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082932&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Follow-up spectra of images B and G2/C, obtained with a similar Gemini South setup as the discovery spectra of Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Both images have the same emission lines, but G2/C is considerably dimmed and reddened with respect to image B.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the ordering of stationary points in the Fermat potential of a fold configuration (Saha &amp; Williams\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), the shortest arrival time corresponds to image A (minimum), followed by B (minimum) and C (first saddle-point) and then D (second saddle-point). For this reason, \u2018C\u2019 will be alternatively denoted as the <em>first saddle-point image</em> hereafter. Throughout this paper, we will treat this fourth image as an independent object, i.e. will not use its properties directly in constraining the lens models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The DES cutouts are modelled as the superposition of a galaxy with a S\u00e9rsic (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1968</a>) profile for G1, and four point sources for A,B,D and G2/C. Different choices for the PSF are available, as it can be adopted from the DES PSF reconstruction or explicitly modelled as a superposition of analytic profiles. Each of these leads to a slight PSF mismatch on pixel-scales, but does not change the results appreciably. In order to test the robustness of the results, we opted for: (<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) a model with the DES-reconstructed PSF; and (<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>) a model with a Moffat profile (Moffat\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1969</a>) fit to a nearby star to determine a parametric PSF. In the model, we impose that the relative displacements of all components (with respect to image A) are the same in every band. The model then comprises: the position angle \u03d5<sub>l</sub>, S\u00e9rsic index <em>n<sub>s</sub></em> and half-light radius <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> of G1; the <em>grizY</em> positions of A; the relative displacements of G1, B, G2/C and D; and the <em>grizY</em> magnitudes of all objects. The Moffat PSF model (<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>) includes G3.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The inferred parameters with their uncertainties are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The differences in estimated magnitudes between the two choices of PSF are an outcome of PSF mismatch (and secondarily pixel scale), and the uncertainties are systematics-dominated. Unfortunately, the depth and image quality of the survey cutouts are not sufficient to constrain the shape parameters of G. Nevertheless, the multiband magnitudes of G1 (marginalized over everything else) are still well constrained. The (broad-band) SEDs of G1 and the four images are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. The colours of image G2/C can be obtained by adding a standard reddening law (Cardelli, Clayton &amp; Mathis\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>, using <em>R<sub>V</sub></em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1 and <em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00.3) to the SED of image B, but the overall magnitudes need an additional \u2018grey\u2019 dimming of 0.8\u2009mags; we also sum the small contribution of a putative galaxy G2 3.5 mags fainter than G1, in order to better reproduce the <em>zY</em>-band fluxes. We will return to these points in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. These results do not depend on the chosen PSF.</p>                        <a id=\"98082936\" scrollto-destination=\"98082936\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=38tIuXLSvghrgzkGGWA92KzRP~XuxWxcQHVH7tIIVHJTn8KDkRpJiEw-4n~pdhHsfAOj~wbeP3DxaYVUh~vi7GOLicxERdSyf9bI8gDO3JBZ8uummPTnuAcGtciCwzfAfpfarK09c58~cEG9voc9CjJMEUoSZwQLcSpzgXunWSLylE0v8o-GiD2JM0Xbh88NlyHLgMsIIW5r2e8Ed~Aj8TnQyBn~5DKcCc1IRL3zQG~oHNZiUsXJnf~oyIYN9mFUbOAG0RxkOX6tYtTyvwyRFceweR4q8Rl~Ay~F5I0b99PoyDn2hR3mh4m~q0hdZ0ycane47TqyYadV2AFaxQjGpQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: grizY magnitudes of the multiple components; red (resp. blue) symbols indicate the galaxy G1 (resp. other compact images A,B,D), while the fainter SED with purple symbols corresponds to G2/C. The SED of image B, once reddened, needs an additional dimming of \u22480.8\u2009mag in all bands to coincide with that of G2/C (black line), to which we also sum the contribution of a galaxy 3.5\u2009mag fainter than G1 as discussed in Section\u00a04. Bottom: Spectrum of the main deflector galaxy G1 from the best-fitting FAST model, yielding $\\log _{10}(M_{\\star }/\\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}) = 11.49^{+0.46}_{-0.32}$. The observed photometry is given by the dark-green symbols.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082936/stx2242fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082936\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=tdI1gllxkuZM3JCK~p2~v6NhmZhrHSae-6df16iCVZIm1ev934iKQxNtPo6swWjPAfo4DJugBaHe60uRl2qA08Z-ScdWo4yXr4qJUOdKyei1-eFFr9OduI3Vvpc-8yNLJYNBbUhBBcZTYN9Vx8NFdnM-UfgBkokGp2esyUA41DFyXfIaf~UCgyB5vYwShUq4vesqtK1ZN-CNlmJMhCPsX05Rac~u2OY~jBsvDUm7EnCtxwFoYo7XA8R5WryHdPG6iISQdLaWdf7vSdWsYHQszY-rHgAnxNvpX4jNJTgbL1BNl92DPlLzOGQ4sZnGXCEhKxZWgDSWNRrzsCjEC~rHDA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082936&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: <em>grizY</em> magnitudes of the multiple components; red (resp. blue) symbols indicate the galaxy G1 (resp. other compact images A,B,D), while the fainter SED with purple symbols corresponds to G2/C. The observed photometry is given by the dark-green symbols.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"98082937\" scrollto-destination=\"98082937\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Positions (relative to image <em>A</em>) and magnitudes of the objects in J0408\u22125354, from a joint model of the DES <em>grizY</em> single-epoch images with best image quality, adopting the DES-reconstructed PSF (<em>upper</em> sub-table) or a parametric fit to a nearby star (<em>lower</em> sub-table). Image <em>A</em> is at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\rm {RA},\\rm {DEC}) = (62.091323, -53.900289)$|\u2060</span>. All the positions have an uncertainty of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.25\\times 10^{-4}\\,\\rm {deg} = 0.09\\text{ arcsec}$|\u2060</span>, smaller than half the DES pixel size (0.27\u2009arcsec), with zero covariance between \u03b4RA and \u03b4DEC. The naming scheme is illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. With the current depth and image quality, there are degeneracies in the fitted parameters of G3 and those of other components, primarily G1. The <em>zY</em> magnitudes of the \u2018blue plume\u2019 G3 are quoted as upper limits.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>obj.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98082937\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082938 id=\"98082938\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Lens stellar mass</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>grizY</em> SED inferred for the main deflector galaxy G1 can be used to estimate its stellar mass. We used the public<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> version of FAST (Kriek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Motivated by Treu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), we adopt a Salpeter stellar IMF, which is expected for massive early-type galaxies. A direct measurement of the lens velocity dispersion would enable an IMF-independent determination of the stellar mass (Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). The best-fitting model is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. With the uncertainties from the SED modelling, we obtain <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log _{10}(M_{\\star }/\\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}) = 11.49^{+0.46}_{-0.32}$|\u2060</span>. We will compare this to the results of lens models in the next section. Once again, while we used the more uncertain <em>grizY</em> magnitudes (to remain on the cautionary side), the inferred stellar mass does not depend appreciably on the PSF chosen to model the cutout.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=98082940 id=\"98082940\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 LENS MODELS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The three images A, B, D have compatible SEDs, as is also confirmed by their long-slit spectra by Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We can then use their positions relative to G1 to model this system as a gravitational lens, obtaining estimates of the total mass (within the Einstein radius) and predicted time-delays between different images. Since G2/C is substantially redder than the other components, we do not include it in the lens model, but rather compare its properties with those predicted by the lens model fit to the other components. The technicalities of the lens model are described in Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Conservatively, we adopt 0.2\u2009arcsec positional uncertainties on A, B, D and 0.3\u2009arcsec on G1, G2/C, about twice as large as those from the cutout modelling of Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> (relying solely on the DES cutouts). This allows us to explore a wide family of lens models and draw some general conclusions, in particular on the flux ratios allowed by different models. In one case, we also allow the positional uncertainties to be those given directly by the cutout modelling (last line of Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). The inferred lens model parameters for all models are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We stress that we are not using the smaller uncertainties from the WFI deconvolution, in order to highlight the robustness of some conclusions that held already with DES-quality data. However, when ellipticity is included in the lens model (defined as \u2018SIE\u2019 below), its p.a. agrees well with that from the WFI images shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98082943\" scrollto-destination=\"98082943\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inferred lens model parameters in the case of a Singular Isothermal Ellipsoid (SIE, first row), a Singular Isothermal Sphere plus external shear (SIS+XS, second row), or the same plus a small perturber G2 where G2/C is observed in the DES cutouts, adopting 0.2\u2009arcsec for the positional uncertainties of <em>A, B, D</em> and 0.3\u2009arcsec for those of G1 and G2. For reference, the notation is fully explained in the main text. The number of degrees of freedom of each model corresponds simply to the number of parameters that are not kept fixed in this table. The lens p.a. of G1 (which may be different from that of its starlight) is quoted in \u2018mathematical notation\u2019 N of W, corresponding to \u224830\u2009deg E of N. The perturber Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E, <em>p</em></sub> is not an additional parameter, being inferred directly from <em>b<sub>p</sub></em> and <em>s<sub>p</sub></em>. Models with a sub-critical G2 (<em>s<sub>p</sub></em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0<em>b<sub>p</sub></em>/2) are not excluded. <sup>(<em>a</em>)</sup>This line shows the average parameters and standard deviations obtained when all uncertainties on positions are set to 0.1\u2009arcsec. <sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup> The two bottom lines list the lens parameters form a model with G1 plus one (upper) or two (lower) perturbers with free positions, and flux ratios as additional constraints (Section 3.3.2). Letters in square brackets indicate the image next to which the perturbers lie.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SIE\u00a0</td><td>(1.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>\u221260.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.0\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+XS\u00a0</td><td>(1.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>[1.00]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>29.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+XS+G2\u00a0</td><td>(1.73\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>[1.00]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>18.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010.1\u00a0</td><td>(0.33\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.23)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.21\u00a0</td><td>(0.26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.13)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+XS+G2<sup>(<em>a</em>)</sup>\u00a0</td><td>(1.72\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>[1.00]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>16.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07.2\u00a0</td><td>(0.35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.19)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.30\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.20\u00a0</td><td>(0.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+XS+1p<sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup>\u00a0</td><td>(1.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.67\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u221258.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.4\u00a0</td><td>0.016\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.012\u00a0</td><td>20.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.0\u00a0</td><td>(0.051\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.008)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.17\u00a0</td><td>(0.033\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.013)\u2009arcsec [C]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+XS+2p<sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup>\u00a0</td><td>(1.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.93\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>\u221259.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.3\u00a0</td><td>0.004\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.032\u00a0</td><td>19.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.2\u00a0</td><td>(0.40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>(0.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07)\u2009arcsec [C]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>(0.44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.05\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>(0.42\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06)\u2009arcsec [D]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E, l</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03d5<sub>l</sub> (N of W)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<sub>s</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c6<sub>s</sub> (N of W)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>b<sub>p</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>s<sub>p</sub></em>/<em>b<sub>p</sub></em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b8<sub>E, <em>p</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SIE\u00a0</td><td>(1.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>\u221260.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.0\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+XS\u00a0</td><td>(1.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>[1.00]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3\u00a0</td><td>29.8\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+XS+G2\u00a0</td><td>(1.73\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>[1.00]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03\u00a0</td><td>18.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a010.1\u00a0</td><td>(0.33\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.23)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.21\u00a0</td><td>(0.26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.13)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIS+XS+G2<sup>(<em>a</em>)</sup>\u00a0</td><td>(1.72\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>[1.00]\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>16.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07.2\u00a0</td><td>(0.35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.19)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.30\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.20\u00a0</td><td>(0.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+XS+1p<sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup>\u00a0</td><td>(1.90\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.67\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>\u221258.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.4\u00a0</td><td>0.016\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.012\u00a0</td><td>20.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03.0\u00a0</td><td>(0.051\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.008)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.24\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.17\u00a0</td><td>(0.033\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.013)\u2009arcsec [C]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SIE+XS+2p<sup>(<em>b</em>)</sup>\u00a0</td><td>(1.50\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.93\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td><td>\u221259.4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.3\u00a0</td><td>0.004\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.032\u00a0</td><td>19.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02.2\u00a0</td><td>(0.40\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>(0.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07)\u2009arcsec [C]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>(0.44\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06)\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.05\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td><td>(0.42\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06)\u2009arcsec [D]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/98082943\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The images A, B, D are mapped to the source plane according to the lens equation <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{s} = \\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im}-\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }-\\boldsymbol{\\Gamma }\\boldsymbol{\\theta }_{im},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\theta } = (\\delta x, \\delta y)$|</span> is the angular displacement relative to the best-fitting G1 centre from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, the <em>external shear</em> matrix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\Gamma }$|</span> is defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\boldsymbol{\\Gamma } = \\gamma _{s}\\, \\left(\\begin{array}{cc}\\cos (2\\varphi _{s}) &amp; \\sin (2\\varphi _{s}) \\\\\r\n\\sin (2\\varphi _{s}) &amp; -\\cos (2\\varphi _{s}) \\end{array} \\right)\\\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }$|</span> depends on how we describe the deflections by lensing galaxies. When describing lens galaxies, we use parametric models for their convergence profiles \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3<sub><em>cr</em></sub>, where \u03a3<sub><em>cr</em></sub> = c<sup>2</sup><em>D<sub>s</sub></em>/(4\u03c0G<em>D<sub>l</sub>D<sub>ls</sub></em>) accounts for the dimensional dependence on angular-diameter distances. In particular, we use a Pseudo-Isothermal Ellipsoidal Mass Profile (PIEMD; Kassiola &amp; Kovner\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>). This model provides a good representation of the gravitational potential of lens galaxies (e.g. Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60a\" data-open=\"bib60a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the deflection angles <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol{\\alpha }$|</span> in coordinates (<em>X, Y</em>) aligned with the principal axes of the iso-density ellipsoids <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\alpha _{X} = -\\frac{b}{\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} \\arctan \\left(\\frac{X\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}{s+\\sqrt{q^{2}(s^{2}+X^{2})+Y^{2}}}\\right)\\!,\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\alpha _{Y} = -\\frac{b}{\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} {\\rm arctanh} \\left(\\frac{Y\\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}{q^{2}s+\\sqrt{q^{2}(s^{2}+X^{2})+Y^{2}}}\\right)\\!,\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>are fully analytic, together with the convergence and the Fermat potential. The expression in coordinates (<em>x, y</em>) in West-North orientation requires just rotations in the coordinates and deflections, for which we choose the lens long-axis p.a. \u03d5<sub><em>l</em></sub> as positive N of W. The spherical (<em>q</em> \u2192 1) and core-less (<em>s</em>/<em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a00) limit reduces to the Singular Isothermal Sphere (SIS), for which <em>b</em> is also the Einstein radius <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> enclosing a mean convergence of 1. In the Singular Isothermal Ellipsoid (SIE) case (<em>q</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01, <em>s</em>/<em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a00), with the above notation we have <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R_{\\rm E} = b/\\sqrt{q}$|</span> as the ellipsoidal coordinate of the contour enclosing \u3008\u03ba\u3009\u00a0=\u00a01. In the case where <em>q</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 but <em>s</em>/<em>b</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00, the Einstein radius is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R_{\\rm E} = b\\sqrt{1-2s/R_{\\rm E}}$|\u2060</span>, which means that the PIEMD can be sub-critical (\u03ba\u00a0&lt;\u00a01 everywhere) when <em>s</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0<em>b</em>/2. The Einstein radius can be used to estimate the lens velocity dispersion via<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\sigma _{\\rm sis} = {\\rm c}\\sqrt{\\frac{R_{\\rm E}D_{s}}{4\\pi D_{l}D_{ls}}} \\ = 203\\, (\\theta _{\\rm E}/1\\text{ arcsec})^{1/2}\\, \\rm {km\\, s^{-1}}\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>while the projected mass within <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nM_{p}(R_{\\text{E}}) = \\pi \\Sigma _{\\rm cr}R_{\\text{E}}^{2} \\ = 2.0*10^{11}(\\theta _{\\rm E}/1\\text{ arcsec})^{2}\\, \\mathrm{M}_{{\\odot }}\\, ,\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>regardless of the lens model. Here and in what follows, \u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>R</em><sub>E</sub>/<em>D<sub>l</sub></em> is the Einstein radius in angular units, the same as for the lens strength parameter <em>b</em>.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=98082945 id=\"98082945\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Models with one deflector</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For the first models, we describe the lensing mass distribution as given solely by G1. The first model (SIE) comprises simply a SIE representing G1. The second model (SIS+XS) adopts an SIS for G1, with the addition of external shear with non-null \u03b3<sub><em>s</em></sub>. The resulting parameters are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Both the SIE and SIS+XS models reproduce the positions of images A,B,D and predict a saddle-point image \u2018C\u2019 near the position G2/C found in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), whose relative position can vary from model to model, still within one or two DES pixels. The inferred Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E, <em>l</em></sub> of G1 is slightly less than half the A-to-B image separation (\u22482.2\u2009arcsec), due to quadrupole contributions to the deflection either by ellipticity or by shear.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> The lens velocity dispersion and mass within <em>R</em><sub>E</sub> can be estimated as (286\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06) km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and (7.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6)10<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> [resp. (280\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06) km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and (7.0\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6)10<sup>11</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>] for the SIE (resp. SIS+XS) model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Models with just one central deflector predict that image \u2018C\u2019 should be about as bright as image \u2018B\u2019, even with relatively large adopted uncertainties on the image positions (0.2\u2033 instead of 0.09\u2009arcsec). This is summarized in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, and in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"98082949\" scrollto-destination=\"98082949\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=TxEEQhOJlcJH3x6rOiCKIgyfxOTYJX55IrFJ3awQEK23yfkG4zXKENJo3dcez0yTRjgMVlSfr53FjEte-ZqkSE4wQzsL~DJm9voJvTreC5-XGgSZJQGERhbbdsYAeYPlY-a6RSpXrlhbC9uM0EWmKh3p4RvwRzV3~zXVP4o3ud3p8msg83eBbNu4-I7a4ldhiFbhqJdK~2V-NJFDmhTXEf4kBCjgF4c54wdop3sJH~MVyguVIHt3ItBOxpgcrPBwrZKUuYlmCW3MRIr0y70E0BfydriqvueXX8p8-KXhQFioLKPQwM--bXyyevHJHEpGuqfKNRDHeu83PAZFaw5ppw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Output magnifications from a model with one SIE in the lens plane; the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior (no parameters held fixed). While the magnifications of B and D relative to A are in qualitative agreement with the SED fit results, the predicted image C should be almost as bright as image B and appreciably brighter than image A. This is not observed even after differential reddening is added to fit the colours (Section 2), and so it cannot be solely the result of dust extinction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082949/stx2242fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082949\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=h1fmOgqkWgxqQFm~jIBisO4avvEJ0lwaSBQhiYPlTDJxjMS2ioYXRcJLkcwkLPd6sTol7cOwLGFXZpZTG1UJWW4cqedd5WUKAZvLeq5vTTMbJT5DbPizur3A-0yoVHURd5GuUQaCu4f4BiVbd0GFQXj6y2F3ByT-RiE8tdOmLs3N1nU2g6DEI27A6IpaGvV4N8r4YI~n3-swCgl1xr1DSAakj4HrXy0uMe2DHue4yD0GXvhlHlSE-bmPrkesmE7KwfrETGIdNyi-gyaLNTEVXpzi5FS5iZ-KulBR0dk~wC5R1Sz2BR4ERPjZdFvVBogp3dQ3~kHUd~xqzng-X3aKQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082949&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Output magnifications from a model with one SIE in the lens plane; the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior (no parameters held fixed). While the magnifications of B and D relative to A are in qualitative agreement with the SED fit results, the predicted image C should be almost as bright as image B and appreciably brighter than image A. This is not observed even after differential reddening is added to fit the colours (Section 2), and so it cannot be solely the result of dust extinction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/m_stx2242fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&amp;Signature=TxEEQhOJlcJH3x6rOiCKIgyfxOTYJX55IrFJ3awQEK23yfkG4zXKENJo3dcez0yTRjgMVlSfr53FjEte-ZqkSE4wQzsL~DJm9voJvTreC5-XGgSZJQGERhbbdsYAeYPlY-a6RSpXrlhbC9uM0EWmKh3p4RvwRzV3~zXVP4o3ud3p8msg83eBbNu4-I7a4ldhiFbhqJdK~2V-NJFDmhTXEf4kBCjgF4c54wdop3sJH~MVyguVIHt3ItBOxpgcrPBwrZKUuYlmCW3MRIr0y70E0BfydriqvueXX8p8-KXhQFioLKPQwM--bXyyevHJHEpGuqfKNRDHeu83PAZFaw5ppw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Output magnifications from a model with one SIE in the lens plane; the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior (no parameters held fixed). While the magnifications of B and D relative to A are in qualitative agreement with the SED fit results, the predicted image C should be almost as bright as image B and appreciably brighter than image A. This is not observed even after differential reddening is added to fit the colours (Section 2), and so it cannot be solely the result of dust extinction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/98082949/stx2242fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"98082949\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/472/4/10.1093_mnras_stx2242/2/stx2242fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611466446&Signature=h1fmOgqkWgxqQFm~jIBisO4avvEJ0lwaSBQhiYPlTDJxjMS2ioYXRcJLkcwkLPd6sTol7cOwLGFXZpZTG1UJWW4cqedd5WUKAZvLeq5vTTMbJT5DbPizur3A-0yoVHURd5GuUQaCu4f4BiVbd0GFQXj6y2F3ByT-RiE8tdOmLs3N1nU2g6DEI27A6IpaGvV4N8r4YI~n3-swCgl1xr1DSAakj4HrXy0uMe2DHue4yD0GXvhlHlSE-bmPrkesmE7KwfrETGIdNyi-gyaLNTEVXpzi5FS5iZ-KulBR0dk~wC5R1Sz2BR4ERPjZdFvVBogp3dQ3~kHUd~xqzng-X3aKQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=98082949&ar=4107762&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2242fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Output magnifications from a model with one SIE in the lens plane; the green contours represent the 68percent and 95percent quantiles of the marginalized posterior (no parameters held fixed). While the magnifications of B and D relative to A are in qualitative agreement with the SED fit results, the predicted image C should be almost as bright as image B and appreciably brighter than image A. This is not observed even after differential reddening is added to fit the colours (Section 2), and so it cannot be solely the result of dust extinction.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"98082950\" scrollto-destination=\"98082950\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inferred <em>logarithmic</em> magnifications for the three models fit to positions of A,B,D and G1, with one SIE (top) or SIS+XS (middle) in the lens plane, or with the addition of a perturber at G2/C (bottom). The first line of each block is log<sub>10</sub>(\u03bc) from the best-fitting model, while the second line shows the mean and standard deviation from the MCMC posterior. The last column lists the predicted displacement of image <em>C</em>, in terms of West-ward and North-ward displacements from the best-fitting position of <em>G</em>1 from Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> (identified with \u03b4<em>x</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u03b4<em>y</em>\u00a0=\u00a00). The positional uncertainties are systematics-dominated, as the predicted position (especially <em>y</em><sub>C</sub>) can change appreciably across models.</p></div> </div><div
